- **Third Aspect of the Invention:**
  * The end surface of the one side of the engaging member at which the hook part is positioned is slanted toward the lengthwise center of the engaging member.
  * This allows the engaging member to evade and prevent damage when it moves to the lock side and the boom is rotated to the lock position.

- **Fourth Aspect of the Invention:**
  * A slip-prevention plate is fixed to the tip of the support pin, and the support pin can be inserted into the slot through the slip-prevention plate at a prescribed angle.

• Invention provides a method and apparatus for constructing retaining walls, allowing for taller walls and shorter bases through pre-manufacturing and assembling components on site. This saves on installation and transportation costs.

• Key features include:
- Precast, substantially solid, rectangular or trapezoidal base set on grade at job site
- Face panel with integral counterfort set upright on base with connection joining them together
- No temporary shoring required
- Immediate wind load resistance upon assembly
- Customizable sizes and variable height or width of individual components

</summary>

The present invention provides an apparatus and method for constructing a retaining wall which allows for taller walls and shorter bases by pre-manufacturing parts of the wall to be transported to and assembled at the site. Using pre-manufactured assembly components will save both on installation and transportation costs. Generally, a precast, substantially solid, rectangular or trapezoidal base is set on grade at the job site, and a face panel with an integral counterfort is set upright on the base with a connection joining them together. Temporary shoring is not required with this assembly. As soon as the face panel and counterfort are set on the base, it can withstand temporary wind loads immediately. The invention is also flexible in that the height or width of any of the individual components can vary over a wide range. All of the pieces of the assembly can easily be made to custom sizes.

• Design of a downhole vibratory tool:
   • Outer body attached to a stuck object or fish with an upper end.
   • Mandrel within the outer body, connected to the surface through a string.
   • Mandrel has a passage in fluid communication with the passage in the string so that pressure can be delivered from the surface to lateral ports.
   • Ports at different elevations, leading to an annular space with which there is communication to a piston attached to the mandrel.

• Modular piston stack for increased power:
   • Modular piston arrangement allows for as many or as few pistons to be stacked, increasing the area of total pistons exposed to the applied pressure.
   • Stacking pistons in effect increases the delivered power of the tool to considerably more than had been available in prior art tools.

• Annular dump valve and plug system:
   • Mandrel has a lower end that marks the end of passage and a nearby shoulder.
   • A drop in plug is landed on the shoulder to close off the passage so that a wireline or other tool can be run through the passage and into the stuck fish.
   • The plug is preferably retrievable and has a fishing neck and a seal to help close off the passage and build pressure in it.

• Valve operation and pressure buildup:
   • Dump valve is shown closing off a chamber so that application of pressure to the passage will build pressure on the piston to move the mandrel downwardly.
   • The valve is cylindrically shaped with a seal ring initially riding on a surface to hold pressure in the chamber.
   • At some point, the ring seal moves off of the surface, resulting in the loss of sealing contact and the relief of pressure built up in the passage.

• Features of the tool:
   • The ability to stack pistons to increase the available piston area in a confined downhole space.
   • The design of the valve as an annular ring allows for wireline access feature through the passage before the plug is dropped.
   • The valve and the spring are configured to better perform in a cyclical loading environment without fatigue or failure.
   • The tool can be operated with or without jarring blows delivered in every cycle.

	+ Air flow can be diverted for faster cooling or lower temperatures, but at a higher energy cost.
	+ Blowers and ductwork are designed to provide even air distribution and minimize resistance.
- **Water management and distribution:**
	+ Water is distributed through a manifold tube array or alternative methods, such as trough networks or integral water trough systems.
	+ A bleed-down system and other methods are used to minimize contamination build-up and reduce scale and lime formations.

* The invention describes a position sensor with a waveform generator and an error correction generator
	+ The waveform generator receives an unconditioned sensing signal from a transducer and modifies it based on an error correction signal
	+ The error correction generator determines and eliminates strong static signals and error signals that do not deliver information about the position of an object being sensed
* The error correction generator comprises a comparator, a controller, and a signal processor
	+ The comparator receives the conditioned sensing signal and determines its value
	+ The controller provides first and second timing signals based on the value of the conditioned sensing signal
	+ The signal processor provides the error correction signal based on the timing signals
* A window reference circuit constantly compares a desired conditioned sensor signal output to an existing conditioned sensor signal output and adjusts the conditioned sensor signal output if it is above a preset high reference signal or below a preset low reference signal
* The sensor monitoring system is remotely located and provides power to the sensor and receives the conditioned sensing signal via two wires
* The sensor can be recalibrated at any time by removing and reapplying power
* The low end of the window is just high enough in value to compensate for any offset in the comparator
* The high end of the window is significantly higher in value than a normal dynamic signal from the differential amplifier when the object or process being monitored increases the output
* The rate of the clock is chosen to be slow enough that a significant number of changes of signal level do not occur during a fast movement of objects being monitored
* The DAC and counter combination contains enough resolution such that even if a sensor offset correction signal is generated, the error correction signal is not a significant portion of the sensor position signal
* The sensor determines and eliminates strong static signals or other error signals that do not deliver information about the position of the object being sensed whose inclusion in the sensor output signal would waste energy

The invention described in the text is an improved arrow point attachment system that uses external threads on a point cap to attach arrow points, reducing stress on graphite shafts. The point cap can be permanently or removably attached to the shaft, allowing for replacement if the threads are damaged. Additionally, the invention includes an adjustable balance pin that can be trimmed to adjust point weight and achieve perfect arrow balance, as well as a nock cap adaptor that attaches nocks to the arrow shaft and allows air to escape for easy installation.

• The invention is a nozzle for applying sealants such as silicones, useful in various industries including aviation, automotive, naval, railway, and robotics.
• The nozzle has a bell or hood lower section and an injection button, and provides several advantageous and novel characteristics for its intended function.
• The first embodiment (FIG. 1 and FIG. 2) comprises a main elongated hollow body with a truncated cone shape, a connecting hollow round section with a threaded exterior surface, and a bell or hood shaped section physically connected to the main body.
• The bell shaped section is sized to encapsulate rivets or nuts and has an annular flanged section connected to an injection button.
• The injection button comprises a circular main body, a peripheral groove section, hollow central circular protrusion, and multiple series of radially oriented channels ending in orifices.
• The annular flanged section of the bell shaped section cooperatively matches with the peripheral groove of the injection button, allowing a strong and firm non-permanent connection.

• The second embodiment (FIG. 5, FIG. 6, FIG. 7, and FIG. 8) is similar to the first embodiment, but the injection button comprises a series of lateral grooves or openings.
• The annular flanged section of the bell shaped section also cooperatively matches with the peripheral groove of the injection button in the second embodiment, allowing a strong and firm non-permanent connection.

• The nozzle may be coupled or connected to most cartridges or machines containing sealant which are present in the market.
• The sealant then enters the interior of the main hollow elongated conical body via the threaded hollow section, which is the sealant inlet point of the nozzle.

• The sealant is expelled out of the nozzle via the bell or hood shaped section, which acts as the sealant outlet point.
• The shape of bell shaped section is meant for encapsulating rivets or nuts in order to cover them completely in the sealing material.

• The sealant applying operations may be performed either manually or by an extrusion or manual gun.
• The nozzle provides a perfect seal from air

* The document describes a desmodromic valve actuation system for intake and exhaust function of a four-stroke piston in internal combustion engines.
* The current method of controlling and operating cams is initiated by a timing belt that connects the engine crankshaft to a camshaft.
* The cams are incapable of closing the port openings; and, accordingly, springs are energized to provide forces that close the port.
* The invention aims to eliminate the use of springs and provide a kinematic action for closing the valve.
* The invention also aims to control the amount of air/gas mixture entering each piston and close any number of cylinders while the engine is performing with the remaining operational cylinders.
* This is achieved through a reciprocating cam translating device coupled to a rotary cam which receives an input from a pulley driven by a timing belt from an output shaft of an internal combustion engine.
* A second device, under controlled conditions, converts the reciprocating linear motion at the reciprocating cam translating device into a substantially infinitely variable reciprocating motion, which is the valve itself.
* The rotary cam having a grooved track in a circular flat disk displaces a translating means which is a ball constrained in a slide which, in turn, reciprocates in a slot to achieve the first reciprocating linear movement.

</summary>

• Improvement of engine performance and reduction of intake noise:

The present invention aims to improve the performance of an internal combustion engine and reduce intake noise. The air intake device comprises a tank, a first pipe with a larger cross-sectional area, and a second pipe with a smaller cross-sectional area, both interconnecting the tank and the air intake passage at different locations. A control valve is placed in the first passage and actuated by an actuator based on the engine load condition.

The control valve is operated at engine speeds where the curves of volumetric efficiency with and without the valve intersect. The engine load can be detected by the position of the throttle valve or the vacuum level in the intake manifold.

<summary>

• Method of compressing gas in a compressor station for a gas pipeline, particularly in permanent frost areas
• Includes compressing the gas, cooling the gas, and feeding the gas back into the pipeline with a lower exit temperature and increased exit pressure
• Problem: conventional re-cooling plants are expensive and pose safety risks
• Objective: reduce investments and operation risk
• Proposed method: compress gas to a higher pressure, cool, and expand to desired exit pressure
• Advantage: reduces need for expensive re-cooling plants and eliminates safety risks
• Applicable to gas pipelines in permanent frost areas

• Compressor station for carrying out the above-described method
• Includes at least one compressor, at least one heat exchanger, valve-controlled pipelines, and control units
• Proposed addition: electronic control and expanding unit
• Electronic control operates compressor to compress gas to excess pressure
• Expanding unit expands compressed gas to desired exit pressure
• Advantage: reduces need for expensive re-cooling plants and eliminates safety risks

• Compression and cooling of gas supplied at an entry pressure below the nominal pressure
• Compression can be carried out in single or multiple stages
• Between compressor stages, cooling by heat exchange takes place
• During warmer period of the year, gas is compressed to an excess pressure and cooled by heat exchange
• Excess pressure is selected so that cooling during expansion is sufficient for obtaining a temperature reduction to the desired exit temperature

• Compressor station includes two primary compression stages and an additional compression stage
• Predominant portion of the compression takes place in two successive primary compression stages
• Between the two primary compression stages, gas heated in the first primary compression stage is cooled preferably by air/gas heat exchange
• Desired excess pressure is reached in an additional compression stage which includes a booster compressor
• Subsequently, the gas is again cooled and expanded in an expansion turbine

• Compressors used in the stages can be completely exchanged for one another
• Advantage: allows for flexibility in operation during different seasons and environmental conditions

• Compressor station is controlled by an electronic control system
• Controls actuation of individual valves and operation of compressors and turbines

</summary>

<summary>

- **Engine Design and Operation:**
  * The engine consists of combustion cylinders and expansion cylinders, with pistons driving a common crankshaft.
  * The combustion cylinders produce exhaust gas, which is expanded along with water via a water injection process in the expansion cylinders.
  * The expanded gas creates a pressure front that drives the expansion cylinder piston, and is substantially cooled before discharge.

- **Water Injection and Cascading Expansion:**
  * Water injection can occur at various locations in the engine, such as the exhaust line or the top of the cylinders.
  * The use of several expansion cylinders provides a large total surface area, allowing for the recapture of almost all generated heat and energy before exhausting to the atmosphere.

- **Thermal Management and Emission Reduction:**
  * A water cooling system can be maintained as a closed circuit, separate from the water injection, to cool the combustion cylinders and heat the expansion cylinders.
  * Surface materials in the expansion cylinders can be chosen to catalyze certain desirable reactions for reduced exhaust emissions.
  * Thermal insulation and low conductive materials can be used to preserve heat energy for mechanical extraction and avoid heating crankcase oil.
</summary>

<summary>

• The invention provides a system for assessing segmentations from various sources in radiation therapy.
• It compares segmentations or "regions of interest" (ROIs) recorded in electronic files using the DICOM-RT standard.
• The segmentations are converted to volume models and compared to identify volume elements that are missing or extra between the first and second segmentation.
• The missing and extra volume elements may be measured and weighted according to their distance from the reference (i.e. "correct") volume elements to produce an output indicating the quality of the one segmentation with respect to the other.
• The invention may also be used for periodic quality assurance of autosegmentation routines or evaluation of those routines when they are updated or used with new imaging technology.
• The apparatus uses an electronic computer executing a stored program to receive a first and second electronic file each providing data points describing different three-dimensional surfaces circumscribing a structure in a human patient intended for radiation therapy.
• The volume models are compared to identify common volume elements in common to both of the first and second volume models, missing volume elements of the first volume model that are not in the second volume model, and extra volume elements of the second volume model that are not in the first volume model.
• A measure of a conformance between the three-dimensional surfaces circumscribing the structure defined by the first and second electronic files is then output based on a metric method measuring numbers of missing volume elements and extra volume elements.
• The electronic computer may include a user input device for accepting a representation of the metric method to allow a user to set the metric method.
• The metric method may be a combination of: a constant value, a linear function of a number of error volume elements with distance, and an exponential function of the number of error volume elements with distance; wherein the error volume elements are missing volume elements and/or extra volume elements.

</summary>

• System includes computer servers that gather data from various sources such as GPS, weather satellites, and geographic information systems

• SCADA system can be used to navigate a sailing vessel optimized to reduce drag while responding to wind and water velocity vectors
• System can be applied to any mobile structure that extracts energy from weather patterns, including wind energy, water current or wave energy, and electrical storms

• The system includes computer servers that gather data from various sources, including:

• Weather satellites, such as NASA QuikSCAT, NOAA Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) satellites, and GOES satellites
• Telecommunications satellites
• The National Weather Service (NWS) Geographic Information System (GIS) computer servers and other weather data disseminating entities

• Wind velocity and direction
• Water current velocity and direction
• Vessel position, velocity, and heading
• The SCADA system can be used to navigate a sailing vessel optimized to reduce drag while responding to wind and water velocity vectors by adjusting:
• Points of sail
• Rudder rotation
• Openness of turbine gates
• Ballast draft
• The SCADA system can be applied to any mobile structure that extracts energy from weather patterns, including:
• Wind energy conversion systems
• Hydrokinetic turbine energy systems
• Systems that extract energy from electrical storms

* The invention describes a rolling body guide cage and a method for manufacturing it.
* The guide cage is made from at least one ring element and several guide structures arranged in the circumferential direction for guiding rolling bodies.
* The ring element is produced from a sheet metal material, formed by forming techniques, and composed of at least two flat material ring segments joined in the circumferential direction.
* The flat material ring segments are welded together in a production step before the formation of the axial profiling.
* This design reduces production costs and waste material, particularly for large diameter guide cages.
* The invention can be applied to both radial and axial bearing cages, and the ring elements can be mirror-symmetrical for groove and angular ball bearings.
* The manufacturing method involves punching out the flat material ring segments, positioning them in an annular groove of a rotary plate, welding them together, and forming the axial profiling.

</summary>

These welded blanks then undergo heat treatment to form a surface alloy and are then hot-pressed and quenched.
* The invention aims to solve the difficulties encountered when welding coated steel blanks, where a portion of the initial surface pre-coating is transferred into the molten area created by the welding operation. * The invention proposes eliminating the source of these intermetallic areas, namely the initial surface metal coating liable to be melted during butt-welding. However, this gives rise to a serious problem of scale formation and decarburizing within areas located next to the weld, which tend to corrode when the parts go into service because they are not protected by any coating. • **Compact and rugged arrangements:** WGHs are normally flat and can be optically contacted to the objects they illuminate, replacing complicated systems with compact, rugged arrangements.

• The invention relates to a method and apparatus for testing squirrel cage rotors of dynamoelectric machines, such as electric motors and generators.
• The method aims to obtain the resistance, reactance, and effective electrical skew of the rotor to identify rotor defects, enabling economic and reliable non-destructive testing.
• Quality problems are infrequent, but hidden defects do occur, requiring low-cost tests on each rotor for quality control before assembly.
• Prior art methods have limitations, such as requiring the stator core, using destructive testing techniques, or needing extensive operator training.
• The invention's objectives include providing a novel and improved non-destructive method and apparatus for rotor testing, measuring resistance and reactance, determining effective skew, and automatic pass/fail determinations.
• The apparatus comprises a test head, exciting means, voltage sensing means, current sensing means, and processing means.
• Skew sensing means may also be provided for automatic evaluation of the effective electrical skew.
• The system is designed for efficient data acquisition, processing, and control, with a multi-computer system for highly efficient data acquisition and processing.

<summary>

- Functional Memory Queue Implementation:
  * The invention describes a method for implementing a FIFO queue in a functional memory, which updates data by copying the path to the updating point and modifying the copy.
  * This method reduces the amount of copying required in functional memories, where each update would otherwise result in copying the entire queue.

- Tree-Shaped Data Structure:
  * The invention uses a tree-shaped data structure to implement the queue, with nodes having a given maximum size.
  * Additions to the queue are directed to the first non-full node on the first edge of the data structure, and deletions are directed to a leaf node on the edge of the tree.
  * This approach ensures that each update requires time and space logarithmically dependent on the length of the queue.

- Header Node and Inversion:
  * The invention includes a header node with three elements, each containing a pointer to a separate node: the end of the queue, the tree-shaped structure, and the beginning of the queue.
  * The queue can be inverted in constant time and space by changing the value of an identifier in the header node, indicating which node constitutes the beginning and which constitutes the end.

- System Implementation:
  * The invention can be implemented in a memory arrangement with an actual memory, first and second intermediate registers, control logic, a flag register, an input register, and an output register.
  * The control logic maintains the queue, adds record pointers to the leaf node in the first intermediate register, and deletes records from the queue by reading the content of the second intermediate register.
</summary>

* The invention is about a zoom lens with increased relative aperture, high optical performance, and reduced size for photographic and video cameras.
* The zoom lens has a good compromise between increasing the relative aperture and reducing the size.
* The zoom lens is of the 4-unit type, where the fourth lens unit is stationary during zooming and the image forming section or the fifth lens unit corrects residual aberrations.
* The total length of the lens system is shortened by reducing the size of the front or first lens unit.
* Proper design rules are set for the image forming section to avoid increasing the F-number too much.
* Increasing the refractive power of each lens unit increases spherical aberration, coma, and higher order aberrations.
* The zoom lens has a small F-number, high zoom ratio, standard image angle at the wide angle end, and reduced size while maintaining high optical performance throughout the zooming range.
* The zoom lens comprises a first lens unit of positive power, a second lens unit of negative power, a third lens unit of negative power, a fourth lens unit with a positive lens, and a fifth lens unit with lenses of positive, negative, positive, negative, positive, and positive powers.
* The zoom lens satisfies specific conditions for the focal length, radius of curvature, Abbe number, and refractive power of the lenses.
* The invention achieves a reduction of the physical length of the entire lens system while minimizing the variation of aberrations with zooming.

* The invention relates to a matrix display device for displaying two merged images with higher definition preservation.
  + The device comprises a controller and a matrix of pixels organized in a mosaic of identical arrangements.
  + Each arrangement has pixels dedicated to displaying a first image and pixels dedicated to displaying a second image.
  + The controller produces merged display of the first and second images, redimensioned if necessary.

* The invention describes an improved identification card with an internal antenna and integrated circuit chip laminated between protective layers for artwork printing.
* Smart cards with IC chips are known for credit card and ATM transactions, and can be contact or contactless.
* Prior art smart cards typically have a rigid core with electronic components attached by glue or mechanical means, then covered with polymer.

* Two layers of substantially transparent polymer are affixed to the bonded core layer/bottom layer structure for mechanical strength and image protection.
* The card may have one or two image-receiving layers for dye diffusion thermal transfer printing, with security features and protective layers as needed.

The advantages of EPROM devices of the present invention include the capability to manufacture EPROM devices using existing DRAM manufacture technologies, larger coupling capacitors resulting in higher gate coupling ratio (GCR) and lower operation voltages, and potential for building programmable redundancy circuits on DRAM devices with smaller area, higher performance, and re-programmability.

* The invention describes a method and device for detecting elementary particles, enabling both measurement of individual particles and integration of count rates.
* The method involves discharging a charge pulse or signal from the detector on the low-voltage side, allowing for amplification of individual signals and integration of a plurality of signals.
* A preferred embodiment proposes amplifying individual signals at low rates and integrating signals at high rates, using capacitors and inductive elements to separate signals based on rate.
* Overlapping rates of signal amplification in different amplifiers enable checks and calibrations within the overlapping range.
* Detecting uncharged particles is achieved by doping or coating the detector material with a converter material.
* Fast charge transport detector materials, such as diamond, enable detection and integration of particles at high count or signal rates.
* The device features tapping of charge pulses or signals on the low-voltage side, with a support capacitor for rapid compensation of detector discharge.
* The invention can be applied in particle accelerators, reactor installations, diagnostic devices, and electrical power engineering applications.

* The invention is related to image processing and specifically to face age-estimation.
* Accurate age-estimation is beneficial for businesses, homeland security, and other applications.
* Aging of human faces is influenced by various factors, including gender, ethnicity, heredity, and environment.
* Computer science approaches for aging problems are relatively new and address two main areas: face age-estimation and face age-progression.
* Extracting unique information from each image and using it in an exhaustive comparison is necessary for accurate face age-estimation.
* The present disclosure includes methods for generating a face age-estimation using a contourlet appearance model (CAM) algorithm and an age classifier.
* The method involves receiving first image data, applying the CAM algorithm to extract a feature vector, executing an age classifier on the feature vector to identify an estimated age group, and applying an aging function to generate the face age-estimation.
* Another method involves extracting facial features from an image of a test subject and mapping them to one of at least two differing age groups with corresponding differently calibrated mapping functions.
* The methods can be implemented using a face age-estimation system and a computing system.
* The methods and systems of the present disclosure can improve the accuracy and efficiency of face age-estimation.

</summary>

- Invention background and problems with prior art:
  * Wiring devices such as switches and receptacles are installed in ganged boxes attached to building walls.
  * Current cover plate devices use screws to attach to wiring devices, leaving exposed mounting screws which are unsightly and potentially hazardous.
  * Prior art approach to hide these fasteners is a cover plate with an M-shaped groove to fit under the mounting screw, but it has limitations and does not accommodate variations in wall flatness.

- Invention description and objects:
  * The invention is a two-part cover plate device for wall mounted electrical wiring devices.
  * The first part is an attachment member that is installed over a wiring device and mounted to it using available fasteners.
  * The second part is a cover plate member that has no fastener holes and is installed to the attachment member without visible fasteners.
  * Objectives of the invention include providing an improved cover plate device that is quickly and easily installed or removed, has no visible fasteners, and can accommodate variations in wall flatness.

- Invention components and operation:
  * The attachment member has latching pawls on its opposed, transverse ends that engage with saw-tooth shaped racks on the cover plate member.
  * The cover plate member has a ridge along its periphery and a slot at its bottom transverse end to insert a small tool for prying off the cover plate member.
  * The use of multi-step racks allows each pawl to mate with its associated rack independently, accommodating variations in wall flatness.
  * The device can be properly positioned over wiring devices installed in a wall that is not flat or even.

</summary>

• The invention is about locating and tracing concealed elongated conductive objects, such as pipes or cables, and improving the process when a second object is adjacent to the first.
• The prior art has two general techniques: a passive technique using a gradiometer to detect ferrous metal objects, and an active technique using a transmitter to induce alternating currents in non-ferrous metal pipes or cables and a receiver to sense magnetic fields associated with the currents.
• The invention provides a system and method that substantially improve the ease and accuracy of locating and tracing one concealed object in the presence of an adjacent object.
• The system comprises a transmitter with means including a pair of antennae for inducing a pair of distinguishable alternating currents in the objects, and a receiver with means for sensing magnetic fields associated with the currents and producing an output signal dependent upon the sensing of both fields.
• The method includes producing in the objects a pair of distinguishable alternating currents, moving a receiver sensitive to the magnetic fields associated with the currents, and producing an output signal from the receiver dependent upon the sensing of both fields.
• The transmitter has a pair of antennae that generate corresponding magnetic fields, which induce distinguishable currents in cables.
• The transmitting apparatus is optimally positioned relative to the cables to produce two distinct output signal nulls over the respective cables.
• The system can locate and trace one of the cables more easily and accurately than with prior art systems and methods.
• The invention can distinguish currents in the respective cables and produce an output signal dependent upon the presence of both currents using different carrier frequencies, amplitude-modulated frequencies, or pulsed repetition rates.

</summary>

• The invention describes an apparatus for interfacing a speaker phone with a telephone network to enable hands-free automatic answering and communication.
• The invention includes a timer for controlling the length of time of interconnection and a bypass switch for bypassing the timer.
• Prior art systems have been directed towards the telephone communication side, and this invention provides a device that can be used on a private telephone line or switchboard extension with a telephone speaker phone.
• The invention aims to provide a simplified, portable, readily connectable, automatic answering service with a minimum amount of circuitry and a simple connection.

• The invention includes a power source, selective switch means, a coupler, a timer, and a reset switch.
• The selective switch means allows for selective connecting of the interfacing apparatus with the telephone network to permit telephone operation in either a conventional manner or in an automatic answering mode.
• The coupler automatically couples the telephone network to the speaker device to receive incoming telephone calls on the speaker device when the selector switch is actuated.
• The timer limits the time duration during which the telephone network is coupled to the speaker phone.

• The invention includes an optically coupled circuit and a neon lamp optically coupled with a photocell.
• The optocoupler includes a blocking capacitor at the input thereof for blocking DC components of the ringing signal from the optocoupler to permit cycling of the discharge of the charging capacitor.
• The neon lamp optically coupled with a photocell having a resistance inversely proportional to the amount of light incident on the cell.
• As the light increases and the resistance of the photocell decreases, the current through a photocell relay increases to latch contacts to couple the speaker phone to the telephone line.

• The invention is particularly advantageous for the physically handicapped or for an outpatient during a period of convalescence.
• Hands-free conversation is advantageous for persons whose activities make handling a telephone difficult or dangerous.
• The invention is a modular package capable of being moved to various telephone jack locations throughout a particular installation.
• The invention has a minimum of component parts in a way which is safe, reliable, and low in cost while high in convenience.
</summary>

* The invention describes a content synchronization framework for connected devices
* Existing methods lack support for data synchronization based on arbitrary attributes and geographical distribution of data sets
* The invention provides for priority ordering of data synchronization and bundling of related data sets
* In case of connection disruption, the invention supports resumption of data synchronization from the specific bundle that experienced the failure
* The invention also supports caching of most common server responses to make data synchronization more efficient
* The central reference point processes synchronization requests from connected client devices and returns responses including bundles identifying files to satisfy the synchronization requests
* The client device sends a synchronization request comprising context and dynamic attributes, receives a synchronization response with response bundles, creates a delta list of bundle files, downloads the files indicated in the delta list, and overwrites copies of the bundle files present on the client device with the downloaded bundle files
* The framework supports both synchronous and asynchronous interaction between the central reference point and connected devices or appliances
* The invention enables a client device to have the latest and most relevant content at all time, based on a user's and/or device's context
* The present systems and methods preferably have flexibility to support content synchronization based on device context and employ file compression and concurrent priority based downloading to further optimize the present synchronization algorithm

</summary>

• The invention is a device for the optical recording of rapid processes with a TV camera, which increases picture sequence frequency.
• It includes:
• Means for deviating and suppressing the beam to scan N lines of a picture plane.
• A cyclic line counter that supplies an end-of-count pulse after p line pulses, with N/p being an integer >�gt;1, applied to the beam suppression circuit for picture beam suppression.
• A sawtooth generator synchronized with the counter to control the vertical deviation of the beam.
• The sawtooth generator and beam suppression circuit are controlled via a delay device triggered by the output of the counter.
• The line counter is preferably programmable.

• Operation:
• The TV recording tube comprises a cathode beam unit and deviating means for horizontal and vertical deviation of the beam.
• The beam scans the picture plane, producing a high electrical signal as a function of the brightness value of a scanned point.
• The signal is conveyed to a pre-amplifier, mixed with synchronization and level definition pulses, and delivered as a video signal.
• An oscillator controls the deviation means, and a pulse former supplies narrow pulses to a sawtooth generator for controlling horizontal deviation.
• In a conventional TV camera, output pulses from the pulse former are divided by N (312) for controlling vertical deviation and beam suppression.
• In the invention, a cyclic counter is supplied with output pulses from the pulse former and counts them, with a narrow pulse appearing after the scanning of p lines.
• This pulse is used to control the sawtooth generator, vertical deviation means, and beam suppression circuit provided for the cathode beam unit.

• Advantages:
• Allows for high and selectable resolution in time for TV recordings of rapid processes.
• Increases picture sequence frequency with simple means and flexibility.
• Enables the recording of IR, UV, or X-ray pictures.

</summary>

<summary>

• Dicing of semiconductor devices using pressure to mechanically separate the individual die from the wafer
• Consists of forming trenches along the scribe lines on a semiconductor wafer and then applying a mechanical pressure to the semiconductor wafer
• The mechanical pressure causes a "clean break" of the wafer along the scribe lines, thereby singulating individual die on the wafer

• Process involves applying a photo resist layer across the top surface of the wafer, patterning it to form openings over the scribe lines, and then etching the wafer to form trenches along the scribe lines
• After etching, the photo resist layer is removed, and in an optional step, the wafer is back-grinded to reduce its overall thickness
• A layer of adhesive tape is applied to the back-surface of the wafer, and mechanical pressure is applied to the back surface of the wafer, causing a "clean break" along the trenches, thus singulating the dice on the wafer

</summary>

* The foil electron multiplier is a new generation design of electron multipliers that uses a series of extremely thin, in-line foils to create secondary electrons and amplify electrons in a series of transmission stages.
* It has several advantages over other types of electron multipliers, including higher gain per multiplication stage, simplicity of fabrication, lower cost of fabrication, ability to cover a larger area, and intrinsic rejection of ion feedback.
* The foil electron multiplier can be used in photomultiplier tubes and particle detectors, such as channel electron multipliers and microchannel plates, which are used extensively in electron spectrometers, mass spectrometers, and photonic detectors.
* The gain of a foil electron multiplier can be modeled as a series of discrete dynodes and is given by the equation G = TI TGγI [TSE TG [γSE +1]] N−1, where TI is the probability of incident particle transmission through the first foil, TG is the transmission through a supporting grid, γI is the secondary electron emission yield at the first stage, TSE is the probability that a secondary electron successfully transits the second or subsequent stage, and γSE is the secondary electron emission yield at the second or subsequent stage.
* The gain of a foil electron multiplier is maximized by maximizing the electron transmission through the foil, maximizing the transmission through the support grid, and maximizing the secondary electron emission yield at each stage.
* The foil electron multiplier can handle different types of incident particles, including electrons, ions, and photons, and can generate a growing avalanche of electrons that are finally deposited onto the anode.
* The average total gain for incident particles that can transit all foils in the multiplier is given by the equation G = TGN TI γI Σ n=0 N−1 (TSE (γSE +1)) n.
* The gain advantage of the foil electron multiplier over conventional multipliers lies in the term γSE +1, which represents the secondary electron yield from a primary electron exiting a foil and the continuation of the primary electron with the secondary electrons that it generated.
* The present invention does not experience ion feedback, as ions generated at the input surface of a particular stage are acceler

* The image sensor of the present invention is designed to image in a plurality of planes, enabling it to be used in various image formats such as the simultaneous imaging of two opposing surfaces or the surface imaging of passageways.
* The image sensor comprises a P-type substrate with a highly doped bottom layer and an upper layer which is more lightly doped with a P-type material having a high carrier lifetime.
* Image sensor elements are formed in the upper layer and include an image sensing region and a charge collecting and transfer means.
* A P+ layer is formed between the image sensors and substrate edges, creating a barrier to electron movement and guiding charge carriers back toward the middle of the substrate where they diffuse laterally toward the CCDs.
* Photons impinging on imaging planes generate charge carriers which are guided toward the CCDs by the P+ layers.
* The probability of collection is highest in the storage region nearest the point of photon absorption.
* Charge carriers which are collected adjacent to edges are transferred to CCDs by means of voltages supplied to transfer gates.

</summary>

• The text describes a system and method for transferring network administrative functions from a master device to a slave device in a home network, to minimize total power consumption.

• The network includes various devices capable of performing specific nominal device functions, and communicatively coupled to each other via a network medium.

• Each device is capable of serving as a network master node or a network slave node, with the exception of devices that can only serve as slave nodes.

• The network master node performs network administrative functions, such as beacon transmission, device association and authentication, admission control, and bandwidth assignment.

• The network slave node receives data enabling the network administrative functions from the network master node, and becomes the new network master node.

• The network master node determines if there is any traffic on the network medium, and sends a transfer request to the network slave nodes if there is.

• The network master node selects a particular network slave node to transfer the network administrative functions to, based on predetermined selection criteria.

• The network slave node receives a request to transfer a network administrative function, sends a request reply to the network master node, and receives the transferred network administrative functions.

• When any device becomes activated, it checks for the presence of beacons on the network, and becomes the network master node if none are found.

</summary>

• The invention is related to antenna arrangements for measuring the direction of propagation of electromagnetic radiation.
• The problem with existing systems is the interference from ground reflections, which is significant at low elevation angles and in adverse weather conditions.
• A unique equi-spaced triplet arrangement of similar antenna elements was identified in U.K. Patent No. 1449196, which can determine a function of elevation angle that is independent of the unknown ground reflection coefficient.
• This invention extends those ideas to optimize angle measurements, using the triplet itself, notably over selected sectors at low elevation angles.
• The invention comprises an antenna array with at least four antennae, spaced to provide at least two equi-spaced linear triplets perpendicular to a ground plane.
• Each triplet is characterized by the spacing of its elements and the height of the center element above the ground plane.
• Radio receiver means obtain information signals from each antenna of each triplet, and first and second logic means combine and derive signals from the outermost and center antennae.
• Dividing means divide one derived signal by the other to provide a quotient signal for each triplet, which is a function of the elevation angle but not of the ground reflection coefficient.
• Selection means provide at least one quotient signal, which provides a measure of the elevation angle.
• The array may operate in a receive mode, providing unambiguous angle measurement, or in a transmit mode, in which case the transmitted signal from each antenna in the array must be coded.

</summary>

• In very small dimension semiconductor devices, the invention uses a recessed mask structure to prevent localized high electrical fields at intersections, resulting in lower electrical breakdown. This is achieved through:

   • Positioning a differentiating or mask member, applied for the protection of the dielectric in subsequent processing operations, at a position below a surface to be planarized.
   • The mask position is in the range of about 0.5 to 20 nanometers, with 5 nanometers being preferred, below the surface to be planarized.

• The invention is particularly useful in damascene type device structures, wherein:

   • Adjacent conductors lined with an electrically conductive and diffusion barrier film are disposed in thin trenches in an intralevel dielectric material (ILD).
   • Connections are made to levels above and below through metal filled vias in the ILD.
   • Masking is employed both to protect the dielectric material between conductors during processing operations and to assist in patterning those trenches within the interlevel dielectric material.

* The invention aims to eliminate undesired signal actuation of non-linear components in the signal path, preserving adequate small signal behavior and using conventional components.
  + A receiver input circuit with a control loop for amplification control is provided, with the control signal derived from the intermediate frequency signal and supplied to the part of the circuit preceding the mixer stage.
  + Two additional amplification control loops are included, with control signals taken out prior to the mixer stage and having lower response thresholds and frequency bandwidths than the first control circuit.

* The first and second control circuits perform the following tasks:
  + First amplification control circuit: avoidance of unwanted overloading of the mixer stage and/or varactor diodes in the tunable network if the second control circuit is inactive.
  + Second amplification control circuit: avoidance of overloading of the mixer stage and frequency influences acting upon the oscillator due to powerful usable signals or spurious signals.

* In a first further embodiment, the third amplification control circuit supports the other control circuits with a lower effective bandwidth and signal response threshold.

* In a second further embodiment, the response threshold of the third control circuit can be controlled by the control signal of the second control circuit, enabling better protection of the input circuit from stronger spurious signals.

* The input circuit according to the invention includes the input network with reactance elements, a PIN diode for controllable signal attenuation, a preamplifier stage, the mixer and oscillator stage, the intermediate frequency filter, rectifier circuits, and the control signal processing circuit.

* The control signal processing circuit distributes the operating current to the PIN diode and the shunt resistor, controlling the direct current flowing to the PIN diode and protecting all distortion-forming circuit components against signal overloading.

* The tunable network can be tuned by means of varactor diodes, with a separate supply and adjustment of the tuning voltage for the varactor diodes, allowing iteration-free alignment of all tunable tuning circuits of the receiver input circuit.

- Method for preparing a superconducting device using an oxide superconducting material
	+ A blocking film is formed on the surface of the superconducting material using a photo CVD method to prevent the removal of oxygen
	+ Oxygen is added and positioned in the appropriate atom location using methods such as ion injection or hot oxidation
- Advantages of the method
	+ Prevents the removal of oxygen from the surface of the superconducting material
	+ Allows for precise control of the amount of oxygen in the inside surfaces of the superconducting material
</summary>

The text describes a method for preparing a superconducting device using an oxide superconducting material. The method involves forming a blocking film on the surface of the superconducting material using a photo CVD method to prevent the removal of oxygen. Oxygen is then added and positioned in the appropriate atom location using methods such as ion injection or hot oxidation. This method prevents the removal of oxygen from the surface of the superconducting material and allows for precise control of the amount of oxygen in the inside surfaces of the superconducting material. This results in a superconducting device with the same conductivity characteristics at the surface portion as at the internal portion.

• Sandwich panels with lattice structure cores have been developed for various applications including sea, land, and air transportation, ballistics, blast and impact impulse mitigation, thermal transfer, multifunctional structures, armors, ballistics, load bearing, construction materials, and containers.
• The lattice structure cores can be made of a hierarchical network of trusses, which are synergistically arranged to provide support and other functionalities.
• The hierarchical network of trusses can be made of cells of various sizes, which can be nested and mated together to form a generally hollow core that maintains a low weight while providing high specific stiffness and strength.
• The lattice structure cores can be manufactured using various methods, including injection molding, casting, and 3D printing.
• The panels can be attached to adjacent structures, components, or systems, or can be integral with them.
• The panels can be applied to the sides, top, and bottom of the adjacent structures, components, or systems.
• The adjacent structures can be associated with various applications, including land, air, water vehicles and crafts, weapons, armor, or electronic devices and housings.
• The lattice structure cores can be designed to control the collapse of the first order cells during an impact with a rigid object, making it a preferred material system for impact or blast energy absorption.
• The increased surface area of a structure with a multiplicity of cell sizes can also be used as a support system for catalysts, where the large cell size regions provide easy transport of reactants and products of the reaction enhanced at the catalytically coated surfaces of the trusses.

</summary>

* The invention is a method and apparatus for determining the angle of inclination of a seismometer on the ocean floor.
* The apparatus includes a geophone suspended from a ball in an annular seat, forming a pendulum.
* A plunger with a head is positioned to lock the geophone in place when activated.
* The plunger is held away from the ball by a pin, which is removed by a solenoid when it is time to lock the geophone.
* The system is mounted on the door of a water-tight instrument housing, which is mounted on the seismometer frame.
* The invention ensures good acoustic coupling between the ocean bottom and the detector.
* The system also provides a simple and inexpensive apparatus for self-leveling the seismic motion detectors.
* The invention can be used to determine the angle of inclination of the seismometer after it has been recovered.
* The invention is suitable for use in on-bottom seismometers and can be activated by various methods, such as internal timers or acoustic signals.
</summary>

• The invention relates to a scraped surface heat exchanger with an improved method and apparatus for mounting blades onto a drive shaft using a pin type connection.

• Current methods of mounting blades can be cumbersome, especially in vertically arranged heat exchangers, where blades may fall freely during installation.

• The invention includes a blade with L-shaped locking tracks on both sides, which interfere with the pin to lock the blade against longitudinal movement while permitting pivoting movement.

• The pin includes an inner and outer finger, with the inner finger having a narrower width than the outer finger.

• The blade is placed at an angle relative to the pins, with the upper fingers aligned with the entry tracks and the inner fingers aligned with the entry tracks.

• The blade is then inserted between the fingers of the pin, with the inner finger holding the blade at an angle.

• The blade is moved longitudinally so that the inner fingers are aligned with the mounting holes, with the intermediate slot extending past the hole to accommodate the width of the outer finger.

• The blade is then angularly rotated downward into an installation position, with the blade restrained by interference between the top of the finger and the top edge of the opening.

• This embodiment ensures that the blade will be installed with the correct side facing up and that the scraper edge will be correctly oriented against the inside of the outer tube.

• The provision of locking tracks on both sides of the blades maintains structural rigidity and reduces wear over time.

* The invention describes a helmet liner that can be custom-fitted to an individual's head
* The liner consists of four layers of elastic thermoplastic sheets with an array of pockets
* The pockets are open and unfilled, allowing for deformation in response to compressive contact with an adjacent layer
* The liner is fitted to the wearer's head by heating the sheets to a plastic state, placing the liner between an outer fixture and the head, and allowing it to cool to a rigid, nonplastic state
* The open and unfilled pockets simplify the manufacturing process and improve the liner's ability to conform to the contours of the wearer's head
* The liner can be refitted to accommodate a changed head size
* The liner resists the tendency to shift position on the wearer's head
* The liner does not require trimming after fitting or the use of drawstrings during fitting
* The invention provides a helmet liner that is simple and inexpensive to manufacture, and can be fitted to a wearer's head rapidly and in a simple manner.

- **Pre-September 11 Aviation Security Vulnerabilities**
	+ Long-standing vulnerabilities in aviation security included:
		- Weaknesses in passenger and baggage screening.
		- Inadequate controls for limiting access to secure areas at airports.
		- Unprotected air traffic control computer systems and facilities.
- **Performance Issues with Pre-September 11 Screeners**
	+ Rapid turnover and insufficient training led to performance problems.
		- High turnover rates exceeded 100% per year.
		- Limited skilled and experienced screeners due to low wages, limited benefits, and monotonous work.
- **Airport Access Control Problems**
	+ Controls for limiting access to secure areas did not always work as intended.
		- Special agents gained unauthorized access to secure areas and boarded aircraft.
		- Inspector General's staff successfully entered secure areas and boarded aircraft 117 times.
- **Air Traffic Control System Vulnerabilities**
	+ Lack of protection for air traffic control computer systems and facilities made them susceptible to intrusion and malicious attacks.
		- Failure to protect these systems could cause nationwide disruption of air traffic or even collisions and loss of life.
- **Post-September 11 Aviation Security Initiatives**
	+ Aviation Security Improvement Act (ATSA) established TSA and shifted security-screening responsibilities from airlines to TSA.
		- Mandated deadlines for security requirements.
		- Required federal screeners at 429 commercial airports by November 19, 2002.
		- Implemented explosives detection technology at airports to screen checked baggage for explosives by December 31, 2002.
		- Some aviation security responsibilities remained with FAA, such as securing FAA's air traffic control and other computer systems and facilities.
- **TSA and FAA Aviation Security Efforts**
	+ Over the past 2 years, TSA and FAA have taken major steps to increase aviation security.
		- TSA implemented congressional mandates and explored technology and information options

* HUD, the principal federal agency responsible for housing and community development programs, has a proposed budget of $28 billion for fiscal year 2000, a 9% increase from the previous year.
* The budget includes funding for housing assistance, community development, housing finance, and regulatory issues.
* HUD's housing assistance programs are limited by budgetary constraints and only serve about one-fourth of those who are eligible.
* The budget includes funding for new initiatives and programs, totaling $210 million, with seven set-asides in the CDBG and HOME programs.
* There are also significant funding increases for ongoing programs, including Section 8 contract renewals.
* However, there are concerns about HUD's capacity to manage such an increase due to ongoing organizational reform and potential lack of resources for new initiatives.
* The budget request for HUD's Section 8 program includes many inconsistencies and overstatements, leading to questions about the accuracy of the funding request.
* HUD's CDBG Program provides communities with grants for activities that benefit low-income people and prevent slum or blight, but the current disbursement and information system, IDIS, has issues with accuracy, completeness, and timeliness.
* HUD is requesting $209 million for a new contract administration initiative under its Housing Certificate Fund, but there are concerns about HUD's ability to administer a new contracting program of this size due to documented weaknesses in its contracting practices.

• Superfund Program: The Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act (CERCLA) established the Superfund program in 1980 to clean up the nation's most severely contaminated hazardous waste sites. The program has been extended and reauthorized multiple times, with the latest reauthorization being considered. Under CERCLA, the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) investigates contaminated areas and places the most highly contaminated sites on the National Priorities List (NPL) for study and cleanup. As of December 1996, there were 1,210 sites on the NPL. After a site is placed on the NPL, EPA extensively studies and evaluates the site to determine the appropriate cleanup remedy for it. The remedy selected depends upon the site's characteristics, such as the types and levels of contamination, the risks posed to human health and the environment, and the applicable cleanup standards. The site's cleanup can be conducted by EPA or the party responsible for the contamination, with oversight by EPA or the state.

• Superfund Incineration: Incineration is the burning of substances by a controlled flame in an enclosed area and is used as a Superfund cleanup remedy. Through fiscal year 1995, EPA had selected incineration as a Superfund cleanup remedy 43 times, or in about 6 percent of the decisions on remedies it had reached through that date. At the time of the review, three incinerators were operating at Superfund sites, and EPA planned to use incineration at four additional sites. Incinerators may be fixed facilities or transportable systems. Fixed facility hazardous waste incinerators are required by the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act of 1976 (RCRA) to obtain an operating permit from EPA. RCRA regulates all facets of the generation, transportation, treatment, storage, and disposal of hazardous wastes in the United States. RCRA requires that fixed facility hazardous waste incinerators be operated according to EPA’s regulations and be inspected by EPA every 2 years. Incinerators used to clean Superfund sites are generally “transportable,” that is, they are transported to the site in pieces, assembled,

* **Medicare payments for ambulance services** consist of a service-level payment for the type of transport and a mileage payment, and are made to a variety of providers that differ in organizational structure, staffing, transports offered, and revenue sources.
	+ Providers may be affiliated with institutions, be independent and freestanding, for-profit, nonprofit, or government-based, and rely on volunteers, paid staff, or a combination of both.
	+ Providers may specialize in nonemergency or emergency transports, and offer basic or advanced life support services.
	+ Revenue sources include community tax support, charitable donations, state and federal grants, subscription programs, Medicare or Medicaid payments, private health insurance, and patient copayments.
* **Costs per transport for ground ambulance providers** vary widely, ranging from $224 to $2,204 in 2010, with a median of $429.
	+ Costs per transport are affected by provider characteristics such as volume of transports, intensity of Medicare transports, and level of government subsidies received.
	+ Personnel costs accounted for the largest percentage of providers' total costs in 2010.
	+ Super-rural providers had significantly higher estimated median costs per transport than urban providers.
* **Medicare margins** for ambulance providers were about positive 2 percent in 2010, but decreased to negative 1 percent when add-on payments were removed.
	+ Providers with lower transport volumes and higher fixed costs tended to have higher costs per transport.
	+ Other significant factors affecting cost per transport include level of volunteer staff hours, percentage of Medicare transports that are BLS, percentage of Medicare transports that are super-rural, and level of community tax support.
* **Ambulance transports for Medicare fee-for-service beneficiaries** increased by 33 percent from 2004 to 2010, with super-rural areas experiencing the largest growth.
	+ The increase is primarily attributable to an increase in BLS nonemergency transports.
	+ Representatives from one ambulance provider organization suggested that some of the increase is attributable to increased billing

• RCRA establishes a national policy for hazardous waste management, governing its generation, treatment, storage, and disposal
• RCRA's provisions for identifying and listing hazardous waste have led to the regulation of waste from various industrial processes and waste with specific characteristics
• RCRA's regulations apply to all hazardous waste, regardless of where or how it is generated, and to waste associated with cleanups
• Since 1995, legislative proposals have been introduced to exempt certain types of remediation waste from RCRA's requirements and give states the authority to establish their own requirements
• EPA has identified RCRA remediation waste as a key area for statutory reform due to high implementation costs and stakeholder disagreements
• EPA proposed a comprehensive rule in 1996 to provide alternative ways of managing remediation waste, but withdrew it in 1997 due to stakeholder disagreements
• EPA plans to issue regulations covering four specific elements affecting remediation waste
• RCRA's requirements can negatively affect cleanups by increasing cost and time and leading to less aggressive remedies
• The three most significant requirements under RCRA that unnecessarily add cost and time to some cleanups are land disposal restrictions, minimum technological requirements, and requirements for permits

DOD policy requires SRC I ammunition to have a higher level of protection and security than that provided for SRC II through SRC IV conventional ammunition. The military services have conducted physical inventories of SRC I ammunition to ensure accountability at 22 selected military service locations in the continental United States.

• Screener performance in detecting threat objects at the nation's airports has been a long-standing concern
• The Aviation and Transportation Security Act (ATSA) created the Transportation Security Administration (TSA) to oversee security operations at airports, including passenger and checked baggage screening operations
• TSA has taken actions to enhance screener training, such as implementing an Online Learning Center with self-guided training courses and hands-on training tools
• TSA requires screeners to participate in 3 hours of recurrent training per week, averaged over each quarter year
• TSA has established a basic training program for screeners composed of a minimum of 40 hours of classroom instruction and 60 hours of on-the-job training
• TSA has faced challenges in providing access to recurrent training, such as insufficient staffing and lack of high-speed Internet/intranet connectivity at some training facilities
• TSA has not established a plan for prioritizing and scheduling the deployment of high-speed connectivity to all airport training facilities once funding is available
• TSA has enhanced its basic screener training program by updating the training to reflect changes to standard operating procedures and deploying a new dual-function (passenger and checked baggage screening) basic training curriculum
• A recent study by the DHS OIG found that while incorporating the standard operating procedures into the curricula was a positive step, a number of screener job tasks were incompletely addressed in or were absent from the basic training courses.

<summary>

• The Internet's domain name system (DNS) is crucial for commerce, vital services, and the translation of domain names into Internet addresses.

• The DNS relies on a set of 13 root servers, which are responsible for coordinating the translation of domain names into Internet addresses.

• The U.S. government supported the implementation of the DNS for nearly a decade, but in 1998, it began a process to transition technical responsibility to the private sector.

• ICANN, a not-for-profit organization, was established to manage the DNS and has made progress in increasing competition, but has faced challenges in improving stability, security, and representation.

• The White Paper, which outlines the guiding principles of the transition, designated the stability and security of the Internet as the top priority.

• However, efforts to enhance the stability and security of the DNS have been behind schedule, and formalizing relationships among parties involved in running the DNS has also been slow.
</summary>

<summary>

• **Source Document Analysis**: The source document is a report by the Government Accountability Office (GAO) on the Department of Defense's (DOD) illegal and otherwise improper closed account adjustments.

• **Reversal of Illegal Adjustments**: DOD has agreed to reverse $592 million of the $615 million identified as illegal and otherwise improper adjustments. However, due to DOD's accounting accuracy problems, additional accounting problems have been identified, making it difficult to determine the remaining amount to be corrected.

• **Impact of Reversals**: The reversals have identified additional accounting errors in 30 of the 45 contracts, involving over $457 million of the reversed transactions. DFAS estimates that it will take over 21,000 hours to correct the accounting for these contracts.

• **DFAS Controls and Procedures**: The GAO had previously reported that DFAS's contract reconciliation system and other controls necessary to ensure proper adjustments were not in place. DOD was in the process of upgrading CRS and correcting other control problems, but these actions were not completed until the end of fiscal year 2001. As a result, the $1.9 billion of closed account adjustments made during fiscal year 2001 were not legally and properly made.

• **Recommendations and Conclusion**: The GAO recommends that DOD direct the Under Secretary of Defense (Comptroller) to ensure that DFAS Columbus completes its review and correction of the remaining fiscal year 2000 illegal and otherwise improper adjustments, reverse closed account adjustments made during fiscal year 2001, determine the entries necessary to correct the accounting for reversed fiscal year 2001 transactions, and continue with DFAS's top-level management attention and monitoring of the program for future adjustments to closed appropriation accounts.
</summary>

• Ginnie Mae, a government-owned corporation, operates in the secondary mortgage market, providing guarantees for mortgage-backed securities (MBS) backed by government-insured loans.
• Ginnie Mae's primary mission is to expand affordable housing in America by linking capital markets to the nation's housing markets.
• Ginnie Mae guarantees timely payment of principal and interest on securities supported by pools of government-backed loans, regardless of whether the borrower makes the underlying mortgage payment or the issuer makes timely payments on the MBS.
• Ginnie Mae has several different products, including Ginnie Mae I, Ginnie Mae II, and Multiclass Securities Program, which include Real Estate Mortgage Investment Conduits (REMIC) and Ginnie Mae Platinum Securities.
• Ginnie Mae does not buy or sell loans or issue MBS, but rather provides guarantees for MBS issued by private entities.
• Ginnie Mae charges issuers a guarantee fee for providing its guarantee of timely payment, which varies depending on the product.
• Ginnie Mae's market share of new issuances and volume outstanding has declined over the last 20 years, both in terms of new issuances and volume outstanding, largely because FHA and VA loan origination has not kept pace with growth in the overall mortgage market and because securitization of conventional mortgages has become far more prevalent.
• Ginnie Mae faces potential competition from other secondary market entities, but has consistently captured 90 percent or more of the market for FHA and VA loans due to the difficulty of competing with the government guarantee of timely payment.
• Ginnie Mae's charter keeps it focused on a discrete portion of the MBS market, specifically that of loans made under FHA, VA, RHS, and PIH programs, and the volume of Ginnie Mae's new MBS issuance is linked directly to the origination volume of these programs.

* IRS' call center network has 10,000 customer service representatives at 25 call sites around the country.
	+ In 1999, IRS began operating the network as a single call center, enabling call routing to sites with shortest hold times.
	+ Before, calls were routed by area codes or staffing percentages, which could not be easily rerouted.
* IRS expanded network coverage to 24/7 in January 1999, managed by the Operations Center.
	+ The Operations Center forecasts call demand, plans call routing, develops staffing requirements, and monitors network call traffic.
	+ Staffing requirements are developed weekly with call site input and agreement.
* IRS call centers employed nearly 10,000 customer service representatives in October 2000.
	+ Operations Center officials monitor network operations, while a representative handles a call at the Atlanta call center.
	+ IRS' human capital management practices were reviewed, focusing on telephone customer service.
* Human capital management practices of other organizations were researched.
	+ Information was obtained from the GAO's August 2000 report, the 1995 National Performance Review report, and call center management literature.
	+ Six IRS call sites were selected for the study, ensuring geographic coverage and other characteristics.
* IRS faces an annual challenge in determining staffing levels for toll-free telephone customer service operations.
	+ IRS lacks a long-term level-of-service goal based on taxpayer needs and costs/benefits of meeting them.
	+ IRS estimates service levels based on workload and productivity assumptions, and balances service and compliance activities within overall staffing budget limitations.
* The Government Performance and Results Act requires federal agencies to develop strategic plans, set goals, and measure progress.
	+ IRS' strategic planning and goal-setting for human capital management were reviewed.
	+ Human capital management practices used by other organizations in telephone customer service were identified.
* IRS recognizes the need to establish long-term goals and is considering adopting measures used by other organizations.
	+ IRS plans to measure the percentage of callers who reach IRS within 30 seconds, starting in fiscal year 2001.

  * Federal government has held funds in trust for Indian tribes since 1820
  * General Allotment Act of 1887 provided for division of tribal lands into allotments for individual tribal members
  * Indian Reorganization Act of 1934 ended allotment of tribal lands and extended trust period indefinitely
  * Many allotments remain in trust today, owned jointly by hundreds or thousands of individual Indians with fractionated interests

  * Secretary of the Interior is trustee for tribes and Indians
  * Responsible for accounting for revenue generated by each interest, investing trust funds, providing trust services, maintaining records, managing natural resources, and probating estates

<summary>

• IRS' audit standards cover various aspects of an audit, including scope, techniques, technical conclusions, reports, time management, and workpaper preparation.
• Audit workpapers are crucial for planning the audit, recording procedures, supporting technical conclusions, and providing a basis for review.
• IRS uses a nine-standard framework to ensure audit quality, with each standard having one or more key elements.
• Workpapers are reviewed during and after audits to ensure compliance with the nine standards, and IRS' Examination Quality Measurement System (EQMS) collects information about the audit process, changes, and quality.
• IRS auditors did not always meet the requirements of the workpaper standard, which includes fully disclosing the audit trail, being clear and concise, ensuring tax adjustments agree with IRS forms, adequately documenting the audit activity records, and protecting taxpayers' rights.
• Problems found in IRS audit workpapers include tax adjustments not agreeing in workpapers, summaries, and reports, required documents or summaries not being in the workpaper bundle, and workpapers not being legible or complete.
• IRS has historically found problems with the quality of its workpapers, with auditors meeting all key elements of the workpaper standard in no more than 72% of audits from 1992-1997.
• Workpapers are essential for formulating and documenting auditor findings, conclusions, and recommended adjustments, and inadequate workpapers may result in additional work for the auditor or overturned adjustments.
• IRS' primary quality control mechanism is supervisory review of the audit workpapers, but limited documentation of such reviews was found in the sampled audits.
• IRS is drafting changes to the IRM relating to workpapers, requiring managers to document managerial involvement, which may address the lack of documentation in supervisory reviews.

</summary>
