• Threshold graphs exhibit a modular structure, with cliques and nodes connecting to subsequent nodes.
• Fast algorithms can compute structural features, such as degree distribution, triangles, betweenness centrality, and graph laplacian eigenvalues.
• Threshold nets have limitations, such as a diameter of 1 or 2, regardless of the number of nodes.
• The paper explores the broader class of nets constructed by deterministic rules, called sequence nets, which allow for varying diameters and modularity.
• Sequence nets can be ordered alphabetically, allowing for exploration of eigenvalues and other structural properties.
• The paper systematically explores two-letter sequence nets, finding three equivalence classes and analyzing their structural properties.
• The paper also discusses three-letter sequence nets, discovering 30 distinct equivalence classes and identifying a natural extension of threshold nets.

• The lasso method, which uses the L1-norm penalty, has received significant attention in high-dimensional data analysis. It can be viewed as the mode of the posterior distribution, with the L1 penalty transformed into the Laplace prior, which can be expressed as a Gaussian scale mixture.

• Nonparametric Bayesian approaches have also been applied to variable selection, such as the infinite gamma Poisson model, which uses negative binomial processes to describe non-negative integer-valued matrices, and the beta-Bernoulli process, which provides a nonparametric Bayesian tool in sparsity modeling.

• A classification problem in time series data mining is discussed.
• The 1-nearest neighbor (1-NN) with dynamic time warping (DTW) distance is highlighted as an effective classifier for time series data.
• The Sakoe-Chiba band (S-C band) is introduced as a global constraint for DTW calculation, initially implemented for the speech community with a fixed width of 10% of the time series length.
• Recent work shows that the classification accuracy depends on the size of the global constraint, which should be determined based on the properties of the data.
• The Ratanamahatana-Keogh band (R-K band) is introduced as a generalized global constraint model, represented by a one-dimensional array with a limited size and maximum constraint value.
• The R-K band features multi bands, each representing a class of data, and can be adjusted according to its own class warping path.
• Two new learning algorithms, band boundary extraction and iterative learning, are proposed to address the overfitting problem in the original R-K band learning algorithm.
• The proposed algorithms use the silhouette index as a heuristic function to discover the best multi R-K bands and improve the classification accuracy.

• The authors emphasize that the basic hadronization process is recombination, even for fragmentation in vacuum, and that the shower parton distributions obtained are model-dependent.

• The extension of the recombination model to higher transverse momentum and heavy-ion collisions at super high energies is also discussed.

• Differential geometry has been valuable in extracting the geometric meaning of continuum vector theories, with the Dirac-Khler formulation of fermionic field theory being of particular interest. This formulation uses the antisymmetry inherent in the product between differential forms to describe the Clifford algebra.
• To regularize calculations, a discrete differential geometry scheme is required, which would ideally have the same properties as the continuum and the correct continuum limit. Defining such a scheme has proven to be challenging, with difficulties often exhibited by the Hodge star and the wedge product between forms.
• Several discrete schemes have been proposed to address these difficulties, including the use of a lattice to define operators with desirable properties but non-locality, and the introduction of translation operators to resolve non-locality. Other proposals include the use of a lattice with specific non-commutativity between fields and discrete forms, and the use of a quantized phase space to regularize the system.

</summary>

• The Dirac-Khler formulation has been proposed as a way to describe chiral symmetry in the associated lattice fermionic field theory. This formulation is regarded as providing the continuum limit for the staggered fermion formulation used in lattice quantum chromodynamics (Lattice QCD) calculations.
• The two lattices of Adams' proposal can be used to describe chiral symmetry in the associated Dirac-Khler formulation. This idea can also be extended to describe exact flavor projection, which necessitates the introduction of two new structures of lattice and a new operator.
• The path integral for this formulation has been evaluated, taking into account the effects of chiral and flavor projection. This builds on previous work and offers insight into the development of non-degenerate, doubler-free fermionic field theories for the lattice.

</summary>

• Cognitive radio networks (CRNs) have gained significant interest due to the need for efficient use of scarce spectrum in wireless applications. One scheme for CRN operation is to allow secondary users to transmit concurrently with primary users as long as interference is kept below a limit.

• Interference in CRNs is caused by the broadcast nature of wireless transmissions, which also makes them vulnerable to eavesdropping. Information-theoretic security has been studied in wiretap channel models, with the secrecy capacity defined as the maximum achievable rate between transmitter and legitimate receiver while keeping the eavesdropper ignorant.

• Secure transmission in CRNs has received little attention, but recent work has investigated information-theoretic security in fading multi-antenna and multiuser channels, including cooperative relaying under secrecy constraints.

• In this paper, the authors investigate collaborative relay beamforming under secrecy constraints in CRNs. They characterize the secrecy rate of the amplify-and-forward cognitive relay channel and formulate the beamforming optimization as a quasiconvex optimization problem, which can be solved through convex semidefinite programming.

• The authors also propose two sub-optimal null space beamforming schemes to reduce computational complexity and consider a cognitive relay channel with a secondary user source, primary user, secondary user destination, eavesdropper, and relays.

</summary>

• The parallel chip-firing game is a special case of the general chip-firing game, where all vertices fire simultaneously in each step.
• It was introduced by Bitar and Goles in 1992 and has been studied for its connections to number theory, algebra, and combinatorics.
• The game has nontrivial computing capabilities and can simulate classical computer gates and two-register machines.
• The game can also model a pile of particles that falls when there are too many particles stacked at any point, known as the deterministic fixed-energy sandpile.
• The game exhibits self-organized criticality, a phenomenon where slight perturbations in initial position cause large, avalanche-like disturbances.
• In section 2, lemmas are established about parallel chip-firing games on general simple connected graphs.
• In section 3, every possible period for the complete bipartite graph is found.
• In section 4, positions on the complete multipartite graph with period n are constructed for all n.
• The game can be used to prove Bitar's conjecture for certain graphs, but longer periods exist for complete bipartite graphs.
• Further research can be done on bounding periods of positions on vertex-regular graphs and more general bipartite graphs.

</summary>

- **Standard Model Limitations and New Physics Models**
  * Global fits to precision measurements are used to limit models with physics beyond the Standard Model (SM) and infer information about the parameters of new models.
  * The SM predicts the W boson mass in terms of other parameters, with a strong correlation to the experimentally measured top quark mass.
  * Models with new physics often introduce additional parameters, requiring a different renormalization scheme and leading to incorrect results when considering one-loop contributions.

- **Renormalization and Scalar Mass Dependence**
  * The SM satisfies certain conditions at tree level, but these do not hold in models with new physics.
  * The renormalization of a theory with a real triplet Higgs at tree level is fundamentally different from that of the SM, requiring a fourth input parameter.
  * The dependence on scalar masses in the W boson mass is quadratic, and the triplet is non-decoupling, meaning it must be included in any effective field theory analysis of low energy physics.

- **Scalar Potential and Minimization Conditions**
  * The scalar potential of the model with a triplet and a doublet is given by six parameters, two of which contribute to the gauge boson masses.
  * The mixing angles in the neutral and charged Higgs sectors are solutions to equations obtained by minimizing the scalar potential.
  * The second derivatives of the scalar potential provide information about the mixing between the doublet and the triplet.
</summary>

• The text discusses log-Riemann surfaces and exp-algebraic curves.
• A log-Riemann surface is a pair (S, f), where S is a Riemann surface and f is a local holomorphic diffeomorphism.
• The set of points added to S in the completion with respect to the path metric induced by the flat metric is discrete.
• An exp-algebraic curve is an equivalence class of log-Riemann surface structures of finite type.
• It is given by the data of a punctured compact Riemann surface and equivalence classes of germs of meromorphic functions with poles at the punctures.
• A topological space can be associated with an exp-algebraic curve.
• The space is given as a set where x̃ is the set of infinite ramification points added with respect to any map in the equivalence class of log-Riemann surfaces of finite type.
• The topology is the weakest topology such that all maps in the equivalence class extend continuously to x̃.
• The text also discusses the relationship between exp-algebraic curves and degree zero line bundles with meromorphic connections.

</summary>

* Recent progress in understanding physics of strongly correlated electronic systems through development of dynamical mean field theory (DMFT)
* DMFT merged with local density approximation (LDA) based electronic structure calculations promising for computational simplicity and accuracy in band and atomic limits
* Much effort to develop _ab initio_ DMFT based self-consistent electronic structure algorithms, including LDA+DMFT, LDA++, combined GW and DMFT theory, spectral density functional theory, and applications to various systems
* DMFT simulations of material properties require fast scans of parameter space to determine interaction for given doping, degeneracy, and bandwidth via solution of general multiorbital Anderson impurity model (AIM)
* Present approaches based on non-crossing approximation (NCA) or iterative perturbation theory (IPT) unable to provide solution to this problem due to limited regimes of applicability
* Quantum Monte Carlo (QMC) technique in DMFT accurate but limited to small number of orbitals or high temperatures due to computational cost
* Some progress with impurity solvers improving upon NCA approximation, but no universal impurity solvers yet designed
* Proposal for interpolative approach for self-energy in general multiorbital situation, not as alternative method for solving impurity problem, but as a follow-up to LDA theory's approximation design
* Numerically expensive QMC calculations for impurity model display smooth self-energies at imaginary frequencies for wide range of interactions and dopings, suggesting potential for interpolation
* Interpolative approach may be sufficient for solving many realistic total energy problems, especially with computational efficiency and numerical stability considerations.
</summary>

- **Ziff-Gulari-Barshad (ZGB) Model and its Modifications:**

	+ The ZGB model is an irreversible lattice model for surface reactions based on the Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism.
	+ A modified version of the ZGB model is considered, where a random distribution of inert sites is incorporated on the catalytic surface.
	+ The model describes some kinetic aspects of the oxidation of CO over a catalytic surface.

- **Phase Transitions and Effects of Inert Sites:**

	+ The ZGB model exhibits two phase transitions between active and poisoned states.
	+ The presence of inert sites affects the efficiency of the catalytic surface by pinning lead particles and reducing reaction paths.
	+ Simulations show that the first-order transition changes to a continuous one at a critical value of the concentration of inert sites.
	+ The change of the first-order transition into a continuous one is also observed as the concentration of impurities increases.
</summary>

• Harmonic maps are extrema of the energy functional and have applications in various fields such as computational fluid dynamics, minimal surface theory, string theory, gravity, and quantum field theory.
• They are defined as smooth maps between Riemannian or pseudo-Riemannian manifolds that minimize the energy functional and have a vanishing trace of the second fundamental form.
• The tension field of a harmonic map is the section that measures how far the map is from being harmonic.
• A map is said to be horizontally conformal if the rank of its derivative is zero or the restriction to the horizontal space is surjective and conformal.
• Almost para-hermitian manifolds are smooth manifolds endowed with an almost para-complex structure and a pseudo-Riemannian metric compatible in a certain sense.
• Para-Kähler manifolds are almost para-hermitian manifolds that satisfy certain conditions on their fundamental 2-form and co-differential.
• An almost paracontact manifold is a smooth manifold equipped with an almost paracontact structure, which is an endomorphism, a unique vector field, and a 1-form satisfying certain conditions.
• An almost paracontact metric structure is a paracontact structure if it satisfies additional conditions, and an almost paracontact metric manifold is para-Sasakian if it satisfies certain conditions on its structure tensor.
• A normal almost paracontact metric manifold is a manifold with a normal almost paracontact metric structure, which implies that the almost paracomplex structure is integrable.

</summary>

<summary>

• Organic molecular crystals are promising materials for fabricating nanoscale devices, particularly in electronics and optoelectronics.

• These devices typically consist of both organic and inorganic components, with the organic part acting as the active component and the inorganic part providing electrical contact to external circuitry.

• The interface between the organic and inorganic components plays a crucial role in determining the final device performance.

• A common way to calculate addition and removal energies is to use a quasiparticle description, which ignores the effects of relaxation of molecular orbitals due to addition or removal of electrons.

• The adequacy of the quasiparticle description depends on the level of theory used to calculate the energy levels of the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) and lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO).

• Density functional theory (DFT) is commonly used to calculate the energy levels of the HOMO and LUMO, but it may not always provide accurate results, particularly for molecules.

• The formation of the image charge when a molecule approaches a metallic surface has a non-local nature, which can be challenging to capture with traditional DFT functionals.

• A possible solution is to use an explicit many-body approach, such as the GW approximation, which can capture the energy levels renormalization due to the image charge effect.

• Constrained density functional theory (CDFT) can be used to evaluate the charge transfer energies of an organic molecule physisorbed on an inorganic substrate in a more resource-efficient manner.

• CDFT avoids the calculation of a quasiparticle spectrum and replaces it with a series of total energy calculations for different charge distributions, making it a useful tool for studying the adsorption of molecules on surfaces.
</summary>

* Atomic clocks rely on atoms with a stable resonance frequency, but they also require an active oscillator
* Two problems in designing atomic clocks: resonance shifts with clock construction and operation details, and oscillator drift
* Problem (a) is addressed by introducing a wave function parametrized by radiation intensity and other factors, defining the SI second as the resonance at absolute zero temperature
* Problem (b) is handled by computer-mediated feedback adjusting the oscillator based on detections of scattering by the clock atoms
* The choice of a wave function to explain experimental evidence is not unconditionally knowable and can require revision
* Uncertainty in quantum theory creates a gap between explanations and evidence, with the distinction between linear operators and probabilities implying that evidence can't definitively confirm an explanation
* Clocks generating Universal Coordinated Time (UTC) are steered toward aiming points determined by a chosen wave function and an hypothesized metric tensor field
* The unknowability of wave functions has implications for the second as a unit of measurement in the SI, as well as for digital communications and spacetime with a metric tensor
* The discipline of logical synchronization addresses questions related to patterns of channels, hypotheses about signal propagation, and the use of hypothesized aiming points for steering drifting clocks

* The cosmological constant problem (CCP) is a major puzzle in particle physics, consisting of several pieces:
	+ The vacuum energy density can be the cosmological constant and has various sources, such as the zero point energy of each particle and potential energies from phase transitions.
	+ The vacuum energy density can receive large radiative corrections including a cutoff scale.
	+ The experimental value of the cosmological constant is estimated to be very small, and the dark energy density exists but its origin is unknown.
* The pieces of the puzzle do not fit in the framework of Einstein gravity and the Standard Model of particle physics.
	+ A fundamental theory including gravity has not been established, so it is meaningful to suggest an effective description of various experimental results concerning the vacuum energy.
	+ It might be necessary to introduce new principles, assumptions, and/or a framework beyond common sense of accepted physics.
* The article studies physics on the CCP in the framework of effective field theory and suggests that a dominant part of dark energy can originate from gravitational corrections of vacuum energy.
	+ The assumption is made that classical gravitational fields do not couple to a large portion of the vacuum energy effectively.
	+ The conjecture is given that physics around the terascale is relevant to the dark energy of our universe.
</summary>

- Experimental techniques for spectroscopic studies of hyperfine manifolds in alkalies have been improved by two-color modulation transfer spectroscopy:
	+ This method uses two lasers (pump and probe) counter-propagating through a thermal vapor, with one laser modulated.
	+ The pump laser connects the ground state to a resonant intermediate state, while the probe scans over the desired energy manifold.
	+ The non-linear interaction of the lasers burns a hole in the atomic ground state population, generating sub-Doppler peaks and sidebands.
- The method has several advantages over standard spectroscopic techniques:
	+ It overcomes the low signal-to-noise ratio and non-availability of detectors at desired wavelengths.
	+ It can be used to lock the probe laser to an excited atomic resonance, avoiding unwanted electronic modulation effects.
	+ It can be extended to other atomic levels.
- The method has been demonstrated using a three-level model with a density matrix formalism:
	+ The model shows qualitative features of experimental spectra for both amplitude-modulated probe (amp) and frequency-modulated pump (fmp) systems.
	+ The system is solved using a Floquet basis expansion of the density matrix.
- The method has been applied to the study of atomic properties in excited states:
	+ The characteristic sidebands appearing in the spectra can be used as an in situ ruler for measurements of energy separations or to lock the frequency of a laser to an excited transition.
	+ The good quality of the data presented is due to monitoring of the absorption of the pump beam instead of direct absorption of the probe beam.
</summary>

	+ In CEP, the protons remain intact and the central system is separated from the outgoing protons by a large rapidity gap.
	+ The central system is constrained to be in a color singlet state, allowing for direct observation of quantum numbers of any particle in the central exclusive channel.
* Proposals have been made to install forward proton detectors at the LHC, including the FP420 collaboration's plan to install detectors 420 m from the interaction points.
	+ These detectors would allow detection of central systems with masses in the approximate range of 70-170 GeV.

	+ However, in CEP, the b-quark background is suppressed by a factor of ~1000, making the b-quark decay channel observable at the LHC with appropriate proton tagging detectors.

	+ The difference in the arrival times of the protons on opposite sides of the central detector allows for a vertex measurement, which can then be matched with the vertex of a candidate Higgs event reconstructed using the central detector alone.

* The zero-field hall effect in chiral p-wave superconductors (SCs) has been studied recently due to broken time reversal symmetry.
* A nonzero hall conductivity can arise from the intrinsic angular momentum of cooper pairs and spontaneous surface current.
* Recent works have also studied hall conductivity due to impurity effect or multiband SC structure, which could explain the observed polar kerr effect in the superconducting state of Sr2RuO4.
* This work addresses the zero-field hall effect in a chiral p-wave SC originating from vortex dynamics near Kosterlitz-Thouless (KT) transition.
* In 2D superfluid or SC films, quantized vortices are topological defects in the condensates, whose dynamics is crucial in understanding 2D phase transition phenomena.
* KT suggested a static theory relating a phase transition observed in superfluid He film to vortex-antivortex pair unbinding process across a transition temperature.
* Ambegaokar, Halperin, Nelson, and Siggia combined this static theory with Hall and Vinen's dynamical description of vortex motion to analyze the dynamical effect on the phase transition.
* The renormalization process in the static theory is truncated by vortex dynamics with a characteristic length instead of going to its completion, resulting in broadening transition observed in He sf films and charged fermi systems such as high-temperature SCs.

- In the antiferromagnetic (AF) ground state of the half-filled Hubbard model, transverse spin fluctuations are significant in both two and three dimensions.

- There has been recent interest in spin fluctuations due to defects, disorder, and vacancies in quantum antiferromagnets.

- Inflationary cosmology and renormalization:
	+ Inflationary cosmology involves the study of nonequilibrium dynamics in quantum field theory, with a focus on multi-field models.
	+ The renormalization of time evolution equations in single-field models has been understood for several years, but going beyond tree level in multi-field models brings in the issue of renormalization.
	+ The authors propose a method for extracting the divergences of the theory, which enables the use of dimensional regularization, and work in the context of a closed time path formalism.
	+ The mass matrix is allowed to be non-diagonal for all times, and the mixing between fields is accounted for by expanding each field in terms of all of the in-state creation and annihilation operators.

- Two-field models in inflationary cosmology:
	+ The authors demonstrate the formalism with two examples: a simple reheating model and a hybrid inflation model motivated by supersymmetry.
	+ The mixing effects of the fields are investigated, and it is shown that neglecting the mixing could lead to incomplete results.
	+ The effective mass corrections for the two fields are different in some regimes, which can lead to a chaotic trajectory for the renormalized field equations of motion.
	+ This suggests that supersymmetric hybrid models can lose some of their attractiveness compared to general hybrid models.

- Renormalization of the energy density:
	+ The energy density is renormalized by extracting the divergent terms appearing in the mode integrals, which requires a method of extracting the divergences of the mode integrals.

	+ There are also finite corrections to the couplings and mass, which are contributing to the energy density.
	+ The full, finite equations of motion are then derived, which are independent of the initial conditions of the mean fields.

* The existence and thermal relic abundance of dark matter (DM) have been established by the WMAP experiment.
  + A promising candidate for DM is the weakly interacting massive particle (WIMP), which can be accommodated in models beyond the Standard Model (SM) by introducing an inert scalar field.
  + The stability of the DM candidate is ensured by an imposed Z2 parity.
* Neutrino oscillation measurements have confirmed that neutrinos have nonzero but tiny masses compared to the electroweak scale.
  + The different flavor structure of neutrinos from that of quarks and leptons suggests that neutrino masses are of Majorana type.
  + Many models have been proposed to explain tiny neutrino masses, with the seesaw mechanism and the Higgs triplet model (HTM) being the simplest ways.
  + However, these scenarios do not contain a DM candidate.
* In models where tiny neutrino masses are generated by higher orders of perturbation, the DM candidate can be naturally contained.
  + In models in refs., the Yukawa couplings of neutrinos with the SM Higgs boson are forbidden at the tree level by imposing a Z2 parity.
  + The same Z2 parity also guarantees the stability of the lightest Z2-odd particle in the model, which can be the candidate of the DM as long as it is electrically neutral.
* In this paper, the authors consider an extension of the HTM in which a Z2 parity is generated at the one-loop level, and the DM candidate appears.
  + In the HTM, Majorana masses for neutrinos are generated via the Yukawa interaction with a nonzero vacuum expectation value (VEV) of an SU(2) triplet scalar field with hypercharge of 1.
  + The VEV of the triplet field is described by vt, where vh is the VEV of the Higgs doublet field and Λ is the typical mass scale of the triplet field.
* The direct information on the neutrino mass matrix would be extracted from the decay of the doubly charged component of the triplet field if it is light enough to be produced at collider experiments.

• New design for an optomechanical system:
•‐ Microdisk resonator coupled to a waveguide
•‐ Enables study of reactive effects in optomechanical coupling
•‐ Originates from mechanical motion dependence of extrinsic losses of disk resonator
•‐ Phase-dependent gradient forces also contribute to reactive coupling

• Nonlinear response of microdisk resonator to pump-probe fields:
•‐ Reactive-coupling-induced normal mode splitting reported
•‐ Different from previous works using only dispersive coupling

• Time evolutions of expectation values of system operators:
•‐ Solved in paper using Heisenberg equation of motion and damping terms
•‐ Reveal oscillations at three frequencies in steady-state solution

• Normal mode splitting in output fields:
•‐ Occurs in the presence of reactive coupling
•‐ Not present in the absence of reactive coupling

• Parameters for system model:
•‐ Wavelength of laser, group index of waveguide optical mode, density of silicon waveguide, length, width, height, mechanical quality factor, and pump power
•‐ Work in stable regime of system

</summary>

The source document presents a new design for an optomechanical system that consists of a microdisk resonator coupled to a waveguide. This design allows for the study of reactive effects in optomechanical coupling, which originates from the mechanical motion dependence of extrinsic losses of the disk resonator and phase-dependent gradient forces. The paper also reports the nonlinear response of the microdisk resonator to pump-probe fields, specifically the reactive-coupling-induced normal mode splitting, which is different from previous works using only dispersive coupling. The time evolutions of the expectation values of the system operators are solved using the Heisenberg equation of motion and damping terms, revealing oscillations at three frequencies in the steady-state solution. Normal mode splitting in output fields is found to occur in the presence of reactive coupling, but not in its absence. The system model includes parameters such as the wavelength of the laser, group index of the waveguide optical mode, density of the silicon waveguide, length, width, height, mechanical quality factor, and pump power, and the work is done in the stable regime of the system.

• The behavior of Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD) at finite baryon density and low temperature is crucial for astrophysics to understand compact stars and supernovae.
• Sufficiently cold and dense baryonic matter is in the color superconducting phase, which was proposed by Frautschi and Barrois based on one-gluon exchange.
• The color superconducting phase may exist in the central region of compact stars, but the charge neutrality condition and beta equilibrium are required, which can cause mismatch between the Fermi surfaces of the pairing quarks.
• The Cooper pairing will eventually be destroyed with the increase of mismatch, leading to a first-order phase transition or a non-uniform Larkin-Ovchinnikov-Fudde-Ferrell (LOFF) state in a certain window of moderate mismatch.
• The charge neutrality condition plays an essential role in determining the ground state of the neutral system. If the charge neutrality condition is satisfied globally and the surface tension is small, the mixed phase will be favored.
• Homogeneous neutral cold-dense quark matter can be in the gapless 2SC (g2sc) or gapless CFL (gcfl) phase, depending on the flavor structure of the system.
• The existence of thermal stable gapless color superconducting phases was confirmed and generalized to finite temperatures. Recent results show that the g2sc and gcfl phases can exist at moderate baryon density in the color superconducting phase diagram.
• In the g2sc phase, the Meissner screening masses for five gluons corresponding to broken generators become imaginary, indicating a type of chromomagnetic instability. This instability might be cured by a LOFF state or a gluon condensate state.

- Kosterlitz-Thouless-Halperin-Nelson-Young (KTHNY) theory of two-dimensional (2D) melting:
   * Describes two-stage melting process of 2D systems
   * Compatible with Mermin-Wagner theorem, which forbids long-range positional order in 2D systems at finite temperatures
   * Assumes dilute, unstructured distribution of lattice defects, which has been criticized

- Investigations of 2D melting transitions in various systems:
   * Focus on classical single-layer many-body systems with different pair interactions
   * Examples of systems studied: hard sphere (disk), Lennard-Jones, Coulomb, dipole-dipole, Debye-Hückel (screened Coulomb or Yukawa)
   * Incongruity between experimental and simulation results for these systems
</summary>

The Kosterlitz-Thouless-Halperin-Nelson-Young (KTHNY) theory is a widely accepted theory describing the two-stage melting process of two-dimensional (2D) systems. It is compatible with the Mermin-Wagner theorem, which forbids long-range positional order in 2D systems at finite temperatures. However, the KTHNY theory assumes a dilute, unstructured distribution of lattice defects, which has been criticized.

Investigations of 2D melting transitions have been conducted in various systems, with a focus on classical single-layer many-body systems with different pair interactions. Examples of systems studied include hard sphere (disk), Lennard-Jones, Coulomb, dipole-dipole, and Debye-Hückel (screened Coulomb or Yukawa) systems. There is incongruity between experimental and simulation results for these systems.

• The Kepler mission has discovered over 4100 planetary candidates, leading to a better understanding of planet occurrence rates around various types of stars.
• Small planets, particularly those with sizes between Earth and Neptune, are common, making up a new planet type not found in our solar system.
• Accurate planetary radii are crucial for understanding the distribution of planetary structures, especially when comparing planetary radii within a system.
• A sharp transition in planet types occurs near a planet radius of 1.5-2 Earth radii, marking the boundary between rocky and non-rocky planets.
• Approximately half of the Kepler candidate stars have been observed to determine stellar parameters and eliminate false positives, but not all stars have been observed due to their brightness distribution.
• The Kepler pipeline assumes all host stars are single, which may introduce systematic uncertainties in planetary radii and occurrence rate distributions.
• Recent work suggests that a non-negligible fraction of Kepler host stars may be multiple stars, affecting planetary radii and occurrence rates.
• Undetected stellar companions can dilute transit depths, leading to underestimated planetary radii and incorrect planetary classifications.
• Statistical studies based on Kepler candidate lists also assume all stars are single, which may not be accurate.
• Further research is needed to determine the exact fraction of multiple stars in the Kepler candidate list and to account for their effects on planetary parameters.

• Star formation in clusters:
  • The vast majority of stars are formed in star clusters.
  • During the collapse and fragmentation of a giant molecular cloud into a star cluster, only a modest percentage of the gas is turned into stars.
 • A star cluster will initially consist of a combination of gas and stars.

• Gas removal from clusters:
  • At the onset of stellar winds and supernova explosions, enough energy is injected into the gas within the embedded cluster to remove the gas on short timescales.
  • The resulting gas-free cluster is out of equilibrium due to the rapid change in gravitational potential energy caused by the loss of a significant fraction of its mass.
 • The effects of gas removal on the stellar initial mass function (IMF) have received little consideration in observational studies of young massive star clusters.

• Observational studies of young massive star clusters:
  • Many studies have attempted to constrain the IMF in clusters by studying the internal dynamics of young clusters.
  • Discrepant results have been reported, with some studies finding non-standard IMFs and others finding standard Kroupa or Salpeter type IMFs.
 • Bastian et al. (2006) noted an age-dependence in how well clusters fit standard IMFs, with younger clusters showing a significant scatter.

• The case of M82-F, NGC 1569-A, and NGC 1705-1:
  • These clusters reside in nearby starburst galaxies and have been reported to have non-standard stellar IMFs.
  • The authors provide evidence that these clusters are likely not in dynamical equilibrium due to rapid gas loss, calling into question claims of a varying stellar IMF.
 • NGC 1569-A appears to have a standard IMF based on dynamical measurements, but the authors show that this cluster is likely also out of equilibrium.

• Quantum fluctuation can both suppress and enhance chaotic motion in wave packets in phase space, depending on the system.
• In a kicked rotor system, quantum fluctuation suppresses chaotic motion due to quantum interference.
• In a kicked double-well model, quantum fluctuation enhances chaotic motion due to tunneling effects.
• The relationship between chaotic behavior and tunneling phenomenon in classically chaotic systems is an important subject in quantum physics.
• Semiclassical descriptions for tunneling phenomena in classically chaotic systems have been developed.
• Coherent tunneling takes place between small isolated classical stable regions of phase space in a double-well potential with oscillatory driving force.
• Chaos-suppressed tunneling can be explained in terms of the Floquet formalism in a driven double-well model.
• Decoherence and dissipation, which are additional effects caused by coupling a chaotic system to other degrees of freedom or an environment, have been studied less frequently.
• Environment-induced quantum decoherence has been studied since the mid-eighties.
• Quantum dissipation due to interaction with chaotic degrees of freedom has also been studied.

* The glass transition, a topic of statistical physics, is associated with a sharp increase in relaxation times and a departure from equilibrium in experiments.
	+ Theoretically, it is proposed that this transition is triggered by an underlying thermodynamic transition, known as the "ideal" glass transition, occurring at the Kauzmann temperature.
	+ However, this view is questioned by experimental data and simulations of polydisperse hard-core disks, which fail to detect any evidence of a thermodynamic transition.
* The Mode-Coupling Theory (MCT) is an alternative theoretical consideration that attempts to connect glass transition phenomena with the rapid increase in relaxation times near a critical temperature.
	+ The MCT predicts a transition from a high-temperature liquid state to a low-temperature arrested state at a critical temperature.
	+ Simulations have been conducted using models introduced by Stillinger and Weber and by Kob and Andersen, which have helped shape current views about the glass transition.
* The present contribution investigates a molecular dynamics (MD) simulation model adapted to the glass-forming NiZr transition metal system.
	+ The NiZr system is well-studied and is a constituent of multi-component massive metallic glasses.
	+ The study focuses on the composition and determines the critical temperature (Tc) using the nonergodicity parameter, the α-parameter in the ergodic regime, and the diffusion coefficients.

• **Modeling Longitudinal Data:**

•• The correlation within dyads is accounted for using random effects.
•• The model allows a subject's outcome to depend on their own and the other member's characteristics.
•• The parameters of the proposed model have appealing interpretations as "actor" and "partner" effects.

• **Accounting for Nonignorable Dropout:**

•• A discrete time survival model is adopted to link the dropout process with the longitudinal measurement process.
•• The data augment method is used to address the complex missing data problem caused by dropout and interdependence within dyads.

• **Simulation Study:**

•• The proposed method yields consistent estimates with correct coverage rates.

• **Application to Breast Cancer Study:**

•• The proposed method identifies more "partner" effects than methods that ignore the missing data.
•• This extra information can be useful for the design of more efficient depression prevention programs for breast cancer patients.

• **Assumptions and Limitations:**

•• The proposed dropout model assumes that time-dependent covariates have captured all important time-dependent factors that influence dropout.
•• A more flexible approach is to include a time-dependent random effect to represent all unmeasured time-variant factors that influence dropout.
•• The common random effect may not be the most effective modeling approach when dropout mostly occurs at the dyad level.
•• A more effective approach is to put a hierarchical structure on the coefficients of common covariates to reflect that dropout is almost always at the dyad level.

* Quantum fluctuations of electric and magnetic fields give rise to a zero-point energy that never vanishes, even in the absence of electromagnetic sources.
	+ In 1948, Casimir predicted that two electrically neutral metallic parallel plates in vacuum should attract each other with a force inversely proportional to the fourth power of separation.
	+ The plates act as a cavity where only the electromagnetic modes that have nodes on both the walls can exist.
	+ The zero-point energy (per unit area) when the plates are kept at close distance is smaller than when the plates are at infinite separation.
	+ The plates thus attract each other to reduce the energy associated with the fluctuations of the electromagnetic field.
* Lifshitz, Dzyaloshinskii, and Pitaevskii generalized Casimir's theory to isotropic dielectrics.
	+ The force between two uncharged parallel plates with arbitrary dielectric functions can be derived according to an analytical formula that relates the Helmholtz free energy associated with the fluctuations of the electromagnetic field to the dielectric functions of the interacting materials and of the medium in which they are immersed.
	+ At very short distances, Lifshitz's theory provides a complete description of the non-retarded van der Waals force.
	+ At larger separations, retardation effects give rise to a long-range interaction that in the case of two ideal metals in vacuum reduces to Casimir's result.
	+ Lifshitz's equation also shows that two plates made out of the same material always attract, regardless of the choice of the intervening medium.
	+ For slabs of different materials, the sign of the force depends on the dielectric properties of the medium in which they are immersed.
	+ While the force is always attractive in vacuum, there are situations for which a properly chosen liquid will cause the two plates to repel each other.
* One of the limitations of Lifshitz's theory is the assumption that the dielectric properties of the interacting materials are isotropic.

* The document discusses the computation of couplings in Conformal Field Theory (CFT) and how it can be done using integrability and the AdS/CFT correspondence.
* The authors explore new methods to compute the couplings C<sub>ijk</sub> for certain single trace operators in N=4 supersymmetric Yang-Mills theory (SYM) in the planar limit and for any value of the coupling constant.
* At weak coupling, these couplings can be evaluated using perturbation theory and Feynman diagrams. However, this approach is unpractical for obtaining exact results for general operators.
* A more promising approach is to explore integrability of planar N=4 SYM. However, how integrability will enter computations of the couplings C<sub>ijk</sub> remains unclear.
* One strategy to compute the couplings in a CFT is to deform the theory from its fixed point with a marginal or irrelevant operator. This deformation introduces new divergences in the renormalised operators of the critical theory, which are determined by the couplings C<sub>ij</sub>.
* In planar N=4 SYM, finding the action of such matrix on operators diagonalised by means of the Bethe ansatz is a new method to compute the couplings C<sub>ij</sub>.
* At strong coupling, the AdS/CFT correspondence can be used to compute the couplings C<sub>ijk</sub>. The duality relates the string partition function, computed with suitable boundary condition, to the generating functional for correlation functions of the gauge theory.
* A path integral approach to compute the string theory partition function for a heavy string state propagating between two boundary points has been developed. In this case, the string path integral is dominated by a classical saddle point, giving a new method to compute at strong coupling the 2-point function of single trace operators with a large number of basic fields.
* The authors extend this computation to the case of a 3-point function with an additional chiral operator. They show how to implement these ideas in the case of the coupling deformation, which is an exact deformation.

* The lack of tools to analyze network adaptation mechanisms results in an absence of effective methodologies for utilizing adaptation mechanisms to contain spreading processes.
* In this research direction, the authors derive an explicit expression for a lower bound on the epidemic threshold of the ASIS model for arbitrary networks and heterogeneous node/edge dynamics.
* They also propose an efficient algorithm for optimally tuning the adaptation rates of an arbitrary network to eradicate an epidemic outbreak in the ASIS model.

• The backreaction of accelerated particles on the shock is a key issue, changing the spectrum of particles and shock structure.

• Shock acceleration of particles is a widely studied phenomenon, with much understood but some issues still under debate.
• The backreaction of accelerated particles on the shock is a key issue, changing the spectrum of particles and shock structure.
	+ This phenomenon is known as the violation of the test particle approximation.
	+ It occurs when the acceleration process becomes sufficiently efficient to generate pressures of the accelerated particles which are comparable with the incoming gas kinetic pressure.
• Three approaches exist to account for this backreaction: numerical simulations, fluid approach, and analytical methods.
	+ Numerical simulations allow a self-consistent treatment of several effects.
	+ The fluid approach treats cosmic rays as a relativistic second fluid, allowing for the thermodynamics of modified shocks but not providing information about the spectrum of accelerated particles.
	+ Analytical methods can be helpful to understand the physics of nonlinear effects in a way that simulations may not achieve due to their intrinsic complexity.

- Channel model and achievable rates
  - Users exchange information with the help of a relay node in a network with no direct link between users and half-duplex nodes.
  - Time is divided into slots, and channels are impaired by AWGN with unit variance and block fading.
  - Channel coefficients are reciprocal and constant during one time slot, changing from one slot to another.
  - The transmitted codewords are Gaussian distributed random variables with variances related to the transmit power of each node.

- Transmission modes and rates
  - Six possible transmission modes: user 1 to relay, user 2 to relay, both users to relay, relay to user 1, relay to user 2, and relay broadcasting to both users.
  - The achievable rates for each mode are presented, considering the channel coefficients and the amount of information in the buffers.

- Adaptive mode selection and power allocation
  - The goal is to develop an optimal mode selection and power allocation policy to maximize the average sum rate.
  - Each node has full knowledge of the CSI, allowing them to decide which transmission mode to use and adapt their transmission strategy accordingly.
  - The optimization problem is formulated, considering the CSI, the proposed protocol, and the sum rate maximizing protocol.

- Queue conditions and optimal policy
  - The maximum average sum rate is achieved when the queues in the buffers are at the edge of non-absorption.
  - The optimal transmission mode selection and power allocation policy are derived based on the available degrees of freedom in each time slot.
  - The optimization problem is solved, considering the sum rate maximization conditions, power constraints, and time sharing variable.

- Performance evaluation
  - The average sum rate achievable with the proposed protocol is evaluated in a bidirectional relay network with Rayleigh fading.

• Neutrino masses and oscillations have been a topic of interest in recent years due to experimental results indicating non-zero neutrino masses.

• Several experiments have provided evidence for neutrino oscillations, including Super-Kamiokande, solar neutrino experiments, and accelerator and reactor experiments. These experiments have helped constrain neutrino oscillation parameters and have led to the hypothesis that neutrinos may have a role in a more fundamental theory beyond the Standard Model.

• One proposal for the 3-generation neutrino mass matrix is motivated by an SO(10) grand unified model and has been investigated for its consequences. This proposal assumes that neutrinos are represented by 2-component spinors and that the mass matrix is an arbitrary symmetric complex matrix.

• In an SO(10) grand unified model, each generation contains one light massive two-component neutrino and a very heavy one that is "integrated out" according to the "seesaw mechanism." The effective neutrino mass matrix takes the form of the sum of two terms, with the second term typically considered to dominate. However, the proposal assumes the first term to be the dominant one.

• The proposal is complementary to the results that should emerge from analysis of neutrino oscillation experiments, and together they should enable the reconstruction of the neutrino mass matrix with some conditions.

• Quantum information processing has gained significant interest due to the potential of quantum computers, where information is stored and processed in quantum systems.
• Quantum channels, which transmit quantum information, have been the focus of many investigations, but determining their properties has not been studied extensively.
• This article focuses on estimating the properties of quantum channels, which is essential for reliable quantum information transfer and quantum code construction.
• Quantum channel estimation is introduced, along with notation and tools to quantify the quality of estimation protocols.
• The problem of parametrizing quantum channels is addressed, followed by the investigation of estimation protocols for one-parameter channels, including the depolarizing, phase damping, and amplitude damping channels.
• The use of entanglement as a nonclassical resource in quantum channel estimation is explored.
• Higher dimensional quantum channels are also discussed.

• The determination of quantum channel properties is crucial for any quantum communication protocol.
• Quantum channels can represent transmission lines, quantum system storage, or uncontrolled time evolution of quantum systems.
• Channel behavior is generally not known from the beginning, so methods to gain this knowledge are required.
• A quantum channel is a completely positive linear map that describes the evolution affecting the state of a quantum system.
• Channel estimation is necessary due to the impracticality of determining channel properties perfectly with finite resources.
• Channel estimation protocols involve Alice and Bob agreeing on a set of quantum states, which Alice prepares and sends through the quantum channel.
• Bob receives the states and performs measurements, deducing an estimated vector of channel parameters from the results.

• Quantum state estimation can be quantified using two errors or cost functions.
• The statistical error measures the difference between the estimated parameter vector and the actual parameter vector.
• The fidelity error measures the difference between two quantum channels by averaging the fidelity between two mixed states over all possible pure quantum states.
• The fidelity error is zero for identical quantum channels and quantifies the whole protocol, not just a single run.

• In the first part of the paper, only qubits are considered, described by a density operator with a Bloch vector and Pauli matrices.

• Explanation of dark matter and dark energy in the concordance cosmological model
• Dark matter and its properties
• The role of dark matter in galaxy formation
• The concept of Modified Newtonian Dynamics (MOND)
• Theoretical explanations for dark matter and MOND

• Explanation of the concordance cosmological model, which is consistent with various observational data
• Comprises 4% ordinary matter, 23% dark matter, and 73% dark energy
• Dark matter is non-baryonic and has unknown nature
• Dark energy is a mysterious form of energy with a constant density and negative pressure, causing the accelerated expansion of the universe
• The model leaves 96% of the universe unknown

• Dark matter allows for the explanation of the difference between the dynamical mass of galaxy clusters and the mass of visible matter
• It also plays a crucial role in the formation of large structures by attracting ordinary matter and causing gravitational collapse
• Simulations support this hypothesis, but require dark matter to be non-relativistic during galaxy formation (cold dark matter, or CMD)

• MOND is a hypothesis that modifies Newton's laws to account for the observed rotation curves of galaxies without the need for dark matter
• It suggests that the acceleration of a particle in a gravitational field is given by a different formula when the acceleration is below a certain critical value
• This leads to a flat rotation curve for galaxies, in agreement with observations

• Several theoretical explanations have been proposed for dark matter and MOND
• These include extensions to the Standard Model of particle physics that introduce new particles as dark matter candidates, such as the neutralino in supersymmetry
• Another approach is to modify the laws of gravity, either in the form of MOND or more generally in the form of scalar-tensor theories
• These theories aim to reproduce the successes of general relativity while also accounting for the observed phenomena attributed to dark matter and dark energy

<summary>

• Density Assumption in Early Studies: Early studies on x-ray reflection off the surface of cold disks in active galactic nuclei (AGN) and galactic black holes (GBHs) assumed the illuminated material to be cold and non-ionized. However, it was later realized that photoionization of the disk can significantly impact both the reflected continuum and iron fluorescence lines.

• Relaxing the Constant Density Assumption: Recent studies have relaxed the simplifying assumption of constant density in the illuminated material. These studies determine the gas density from hydrostatic balance solved simultaneously with ionization balance and radiative transfer. They observe that the Thomson depth of the hot coronal layer can greatly influence the x-ray reprocessing produced by the deeper, much cooler disk. However, they ignore thermal conduction and the effects of transition layers between different stable phases.

• Thermal Instability and Transition Layers: Thermal instability allows the coexistence of gas at different phases with very different temperatures and densities. Transition layers between these phases have different temperatures and densities, and their role is not well understood without taking into account thermal conduction. Even though their Thomson depths are small, the x-ray emission and reflection from such layers may not be negligible.
</summary>

* Definition of a closed graph and a closed labeling
	+ A closed labeling is a bijection from the vertex set to the set of integers from 1 to n
	+ The labeling is typically assumed to increase along edges
* A closed labeling has the property that whenever there are distinct edges with a common vertex, the labels of the vertices at the other ends of these edges differ by at least 2
* A graph is closed if it has a closed labeling
* A closed labeling gives a direction to each edge, with the arrow pointing from the smaller label to the larger label
* A graph is chordal and claw-free if it has no induced cycles of length greater than 3 and no induced subgraph isomorphic to a claw
* Closed graphs are chordal and claw-free
* A graph is narrow if for every pair of vertices and every longest shortest path between them, every vertex is at most distance 1 away from the path
* Closed graphs are narrow

• Cold atoms in optical lattices is an application of quantum gases and laser theory from atomic physics and quantum optics, respectively.
• Optical lattices are artificial crystals of light created by the interference of two or more laser beams, forming a periodic intensity pattern.
• Atoms can be cooled and trapped in these optical lattices, resembling eggs in an egg carton, and are used to investigate quantum behavior such as Bloch oscillations, Wannier-Stark ladders, and tunneling phenomena.
• The superfluid to Mott insulator (SF-MI) transition is an important phenomenon in condensed matter physics, made possible by the observation of Bose-Einstein condensation (BEC) in cold atoms.
• BEC is a consequence of quantum effects from statistical mechanics, where particles congregate in the ground state even at a finite temperature.
• The SF-MI transition was initially considered a mathematical artifact until Fritz London realized it could be accounted for in terms of BEC in superfluid liquid helium.
• The observation of BEC in dilute gases, such as rubidium, lithium, and sodium atoms, led to the observation of the SF-MI transition and the possibility of using ultracold atoms in optical lattices as a test laboratory for condensed matter physics.
• The two-mode approximation is used to investigate spin ordering in a double-well (DW) potential, which can be adopted for instructional purposes.
• The DW potential can be considered as two localized spatial modes separated by a barrier and investigated as a two-mode approximation.
• The DW potential is a 1D optical lattice in which the transverse directions are in strong confinement, and the motions of an atom in these directions are frozen out.

- Methods for calculating resonance state energy and lifetime have solid foundations but interpreting numerical results is not straightforward.
	+ The complex scaling (dilatation) method reveals a resonance state by the appearance of an isolated complex eigenvalue on the spectrum of the non-Hermitian complex scaled Hamiltonian.
	+ The rotation angle must be large enough to rotate the continuum part of the spectrum beyond the resonance's complex eigenvalue.
	+ Most calculations are performed using finite variational expansions, requiring the study of numerical data to determine the most accurate result.
	+ Variational basis sets usually depend on one or more non-linear parameters, which must be chosen carefully for both bound and resonance states.
	+ The complex virial theorem and graphical methods help select the best numerical solution for a given problem.
- The density of states (DOS) method can obtain resonance energy and lifetime in a simple way, but there is no single procedure to assess the accuracy and convergence properties of the numerical findings.
	+ Finite size scaling arguments have been used to analyze the properties of the DOS when the size of the Hamiltonian changes.
	+ The critical behavior of the density of states indicates the presence of resonances, with strong dependence on the basis-set size used to calculate it.
	+ The resonance energy and lifetime can be obtained using the scaling properties of the density of states.
	+ However, the feasibility of the method depends on the availability of a known value of the lifetime, making it dependent on results not provided by itself.

• The cataclysmic variable (CV) Hu Aqr is composed of a white dwarf and a main-sequence companion star, with two planets orbiting the CV.
• The two planets were discovered through irregularities in the observed-calculated variations, and their existence is still debated. However, if real, they can provide valuable insights into the CV's evolution:
	- The inner planet allows for the degeneracy between the donor mass, radius, and core mass at the moment of Roche-lobe overflow (RLOF) to be broken, enabling the derivation of the mass loss rate during the common-envelope phase.
	- The outer planet validates this calculation and determines the conditions under which the CV was born.
• The presence of the inner planet constrains the masses of the two stars and their orbital separation during the CV phase, while the observed white dwarf mass provides an upper limit to the mass of the core of the primary star at the moment of RLOF, and a minimum to the companion mass.
• The evolution of the radius of the donor star as a function of its core mass is calculated using the Henyey stellar evolution code MESA and the AMUSE framework, allowing for the calculation of the orbital separation at the moment of RLOF as a function of the core mass.

• The No-Core Shell Model/Resonating Group Method (NCSM/RGM) is a promising technique for treating both structure and reactions in light nuclear systems.

• The NCSM/RGM combines a microscopic cluster technique with realistic interactions and a consistent description of nucleon clusters.

• The method has been successful for two-body cluster systems, but its extension to three-body cluster states is essential for studying more complex nuclear systems.

• Three-body cluster configurations have been introduced into the NCSM/RGM, and the first results for the ground state and continuum states of 1he within a 2he+n+n basis have been presented.

• The many-body wave function is expanded over a basis of three-body cluster channel states built from the NCSM wave function of each of the three clusters.

• The microscopic R-matrix method on a Lagrange mesh is used to solve the Schrödinger equations.

• The development of the formalism for the treatment of three-cluster systems has been completed, and the lightest borromean nucleus, 3he, is an ideal candidate for study within this approach.

The text discusses Thurston's algorithm to compute the core entropy for rational angles and the combinatorial construction of the growth rate of a graph. Thurston's algorithm is based on the external ray landing at a Misiurewicz parameter or the root of a hyperbolic component. The algorithm uses the postcritically finite quadratic map and its hubbard tree to construct a Markov transition matrix and compute the core entropy using the leading eigenvalue. The combinatorial construction of the growth rate of a graph involves the adjacency operator and its spectral determinant. The growth rate is defined for graphs with bounded cycles, and the radius of convergence is determined using the root test. The spectral determinant is used to define a holomorphic function, and the radius of convergence is related to the smallest modulus of its poles.

• The cosmological origin of most long gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) is confirmed by the detection of X-ray, optical, and radio afterglows.
• The fireball model is strongly favored, but the puzzle of GRBs is not yet fully resolved.
• A major problem is determining whether GRBs are due to highly collimated jets or isotropic fireballs, which affects the calculation of energetics.

• Quantum Key Distribution (QKD) is often said to be unconditionally secure, but it requires that the users' devices meet certain requirements.
• In practice, it is difficult for devices to meet these requirements, leading to potential security breaches.
• Some attacks on QKD have been proposed and demonstrated successfully against practical QKD systems.
• To combat these attacks, countermeasures such as device-independent security proofs and experimental measures have been proposed.
• One promising idea is Measurement Device Independent QKD (MDIQKD), where neither Alice nor Bob performs any measurement.
• MDIQKD is based on a reversed EPR-based QKD protocol and removes all potential loopholes of the detectors without sacrificing performance.
• The only assumption needed in MDIQKD is that the preparation of the quantum signal sources by Alice and Bob is (almost) perfect.
• The characterization of the signal source should be easier than that of the detection unit, as it involves the estimation of the response of the devices to unknown input signals sent from Eve.
• With MDIQKD, the imperfections of the sources become the main focus, such as the basis-dependent flaw that stems from the discrepancy of the density matrices corresponding to the two bases in BB84 states.
• To investigate the practicality of MDIQKD, the security of MDIQKD under the imperfection needs to be generalized from previous works on standard BB84 with basis-dependent flaw.

</summary>

• Majorana fermions (MFs) are real solutions of the Dirac equation and are their own antiparticles.
• Originally proposed as a model for neutrinos, MFs have been predicted to occur as quasi-particle bound states in engineered condensed matter systems.
• MFs obey non-Abelian statistics, which is important for realizing potential applications in decoherence-free quantum computation and quantum information processing.
• The possibility of hosting MFs in exotic solid-state systems has focused on topological superconductors.
• Various realistic platforms, including topological insulators, semiconductor nanowires, and atomic chains, have been proposed to support Majorana states based on the superconducting proximity effect.
• Experimentally observing the unique Majorana signatures is still challenging.
• MFs are predicted to appear in tunneling spectroscopy experiments as characteristic zero-bias peaks (ZBPs).
• ZBPs have been observed in semiconductor nanowires, interpreted as signatures of MFs.
• An all-optical scheme is proposed to detect MFs using a hybrid quantum dot-nanomechanical resonator system with optical pump-probe technology.

</summary>

• Explosion models for Type Ia supernovae (SNe Ia):

	- The accreting white dwarf (WD) model is a plausible explanation for SNe Ia.
	- This model suggests that a WD in a binary system accretes material from a companion star, increasing its mass until it reaches the Chandrasekhar mass limit and explodes.
	- Recent progress in the accreting WD model includes the introduction of a stellar wind from the WD, which helps sustain stable mass transfer in the progenitor systems of SNe Ia.
	- There are two main evolutionary paths leading to SNe Ia: the super soft X-ray source (SSS) channel and the symbiotic channel.

• Identifying the companion star of a SN Ia:

	- The companion star is expected to be located inside the supernova remnant (SNR) ejecta.
	- When a star is inside the ejecta, photons emitted from the star are absorbed only by the ejecta moving toward us, forming broad wings in the blue side of absorption lines.
	- By observing these distinct absorption features in the ultraviolet (UV) or visible range, it may be possible to identify the companion star of a SN Ia.
	- However, there is a chance that a star other than the companion star may be inside the ejecta, so additional criteria may be necessary to confirm the companion's identity.
</summary>

• Quantum entanglement is a feature of quantum mechanics that has captured recent interest due to its role in quantum information processing. It can be characterized and manipulated independently of its physical realization and obeys conservation laws.

• In a bipartite system with complete information, the state of the system is pure and the entropy of entanglement can be measured using the von Neumann entropy of the reduced density matrix. However, when quantum systems interact with their environment, states become mixed and the quantification of entanglement becomes less clear.

• To address this issue, various measures of entanglement have been proposed, such as the entanglement of formation and the entanglement of distillation. These measures give the value zero for certain mixed states, which may seem counterintuitive but is unavoidable due to the inherent uncertainty surrounding a mixed state.

• Nha and Carmichael have introduced a measure of entanglement for open systems based on quantum trajectory unravelings of the open system dynamics. This approach considers the way in which information about the system is read from the environment and follows the evolution of the system conditioned on the measurement record. The entanglement measure is then contextual and dependent on the kind of measurements made.
</summary>

• Practical implementation systems, such as fiber-based Gaussian-modulated and discrete-modulated coherent-state protocol QKD systems, have been demonstrated over tens of kilometers.
• The unconditional security of such systems with prepare-and-measure implementation has been confirmed by the security analysis of the equivalent entanglement-based scheme.
• However, the traditional security analysis of the entanglement-based scheme in CVQKD only includes the signal beam and not the local oscillator (LO), leaving security loopholes.
• The fluctuations of LO intensity can affect the secret key rate in CVQKD systems, and monitoring LO intensity is necessary to confirm the security of the practical implementation.
• In a practical system, the local oscillator intensity is always monitored by splitting a small part with a beam splitter, but the effect of fluctuation, particularly small fluctuation, on the secret key rate is not yet fully understood.
• Reverse reconciliation is more sensitive to the fluctuation of LO intensity than direct reconciliation, and eve can intercept partial secret keys if she increases the channel excess noise of one part of the signal pulses when she controls the LO intensity.

• The effect of LO intensity fluctuation on the secret key rate estimation of alice and bob for reverse and direct reconciliation has been analyzed.
• Bob's estimation of the secret key rate will be compromised severely without monitoring LO or if his measurements do not scale with LO instantaneous intensity values.
• Eve could hide her attack partially by reducing the intensity of LO and even could steal the total secret keys alice and bob share without being found by a small attenuation of LO intensity, especially for reverse reconciliation.
• The monitoring of LO would be a challenge for highly accurate monitoring.
• This work is supported by the national natural science foundation of China and other grants.

• The code for computing adiabatic oscillation frequencies and eigenfunctions for general stellar models was developed with the goals of simplicity, efficiency, and accuracy. However, the simplicity is now less evident due to the long development period and the flexibility it offers in choosing integration methods and determining all frequencies of a given model within a specified range of degree and frequency.

• The equilibrium model is defined in terms of a minimal set of dimensionless variables, as well as by mass and radius. The code provides extensive documentation and was inspired by previous work discussed in @xcite. The @xcite package carried out careful tests and comparisons of results on polytropic models, providing extensive tables of frequencies for comparison with other codes.

• The code introduces a new set of dependent variables for numerical integration, particularly for large degree modes, and solves the equations on the interval from the center to the outermost point, which is defined by the surface radius including the atmosphere. Boundary conditions are obtained from series expansions, a vanishing Lagrangian pressure perturbation condition, or a condition between pressure perturbation and displacement by matching continuously to the solution in an isothermal atmosphere.

• The programme permits solving the equations with two techniques: a shooting method and a relaxation technique. The shooting method integrates solutions separately from the inner and outer boundary and matches them at a suitable inner fitting point, while the relaxation technique solves the equations together with a normalization condition and all boundary conditions using a relaxation technique, finding the eigenvalue by requiring continuity of one of the eigenfunctions at an interior matching point.

	+ *Alternative External Source Hypothesis:* This hypothesis proposes that infall of massive gas clouds onto the galactic plane, due to gravitational interaction with neighboring galaxies, could resolve the energy problem. Evidence includes observations of high-velocity clouds around the Milky Way and signatures of interaction in M101 and NGC4631.

	+ *Proposed Explanation:* The authors propose that these supershells have been formed by radio jets plowing through the interstellar medium, accreting ISM gas and sometimes inflating bubbles. This allows for an internal energy source for the HI shells, provides a natural explanation for any spatial symmetries seen in the HI features, and resolves the energy problem.

The source document is a text from a mathematical paper discussing an extension of a theorem by Berestycki et al. regarding the boundedness of the principal eigenvalue of a Laplacian perturbed by a divergence-free drift in a bounded, regular open set. The paper aims to verify a similar property when the classical Laplacian is replaced by the fractional Laplacian with a specific parameter. The authors introduce the concept of first integrals of the vector field and their role in determining whether the principal eigenvalue remains bounded. They also highlight the main difficulties in their development, including the roughness of general elements and non-locality of the fractional Laplacian. The paper uses conditioning, approximation techniques, and properties of the Green function and heat kernel of gradient perturbations of the fractional Laplacian to define and study the principal eigen-pair for the fractional Laplacian and the specific domain.

• The text discusses the use of machine learning techniques, specifically autoencoders and variational autoencoders, to determine phase transitions in physical systems without any information about the microscopic theory or the order parameter.

• Autoencoders are a type of neural network that learn to encode the input data into a lower-dimensional representation, called the latent representation, and then decode it back to the original format. Variational autoencoders impose additional constraints on the distribution of the latent variables, transforming the autoencoder into a model that learns a latent variable model for its input data.

• The authors use autoencoders and variational autoencoders with one fully connected hidden layer in the encoder and decoder, each consisting of 256 neurons. The activation functions of the intermediate layers are rectified linear units, and the activation function of the final layer is a sigmoid or tanh function, depending on the problem.

• The authors test their algorithms on the Ising model and the XY model, which are well-studied and well-understood models in physics. They find that their algorithms are able to find a low-dimensional latent representation of the physical system, which coincides with the correct order parameter. The decoder network reconstructs the encoded configuration from its latent representation, and the reconstruction is more accurate in the ordered phase. The authors suggest that the reconstruction error can be used as a universal identifier for phase transitions.
</summary>

• Quantum cloning machines (QCMs) can produce copies of quantum states, but perfect cloning is forbidden by the laws of quantum mechanics. The quality and type of copies produced by a QCM depend on its design conditions.

• In this paper, the authors discuss "partial" QCMs, which clone only one component of a two-partite quantum state. This type of cloning can be used for eavesdropping on a quantum channel. The authors use a specific measure of the closeness of initial and final states to determine the parameters of the QCM. They also discuss the cloning of mixed quantum states using the "purification" of the mixed state and partial cloning machine.

• The authors seek the parameters of the QCM that correspond to the minimum of the integral average of the "distance" between the initial state and output state. They note that the fidelity of the initial and output states for most of the Bloch sphere exceeds the value 5/6, which corresponds to the universal QCM for pure states. This is due to the fact that the QCM copies only part of the two-partite state and is state-dependent, which increases the quality of the cloning.

• The authors also discuss the cloning of mixed qubit states using the purification of the mixed state and partial cloning machine. They note that the purification of the mixed state is not unique, but the output state produced by the QCM does not depend on this nonuniqueness. • The extinction curve describes how extinction changes with wavelength, which is caused by the presence of dust grains in the interstellar medium.
• The characteristics of the extinction curve are different in a diffuse interstellar medium compared to a dense interstellar medium.
• Knowledge of the extinction curve is necessary to deredden magnitudes and colors of astronomical objects and to understand the physical properties of dust grains.
• Cardelli, Clayton, and Mathis (CCM) derived a mean extinction law that depends on one parameter, which is used to determine the extinction in one spectral region based on the extinction in a different spectral region.
• The CCM law is used to derive the R(v) parameter, which characterizes the dust properties in the region that produces the extinction.
• Many authors have used the R(v) parameter to study extinction, such as searching for a relation between R(v) and other parameters that characterize the extinction curves, studying the role of R(v) as the main regulatory agent of the penetration of radiation inside dark clouds, and discussing different methods to deredden the data and obtaining a new estimate of the extinction law in terms of R(v).

- Quantum computers and qubits:
	+ Quantum computers can perform certain algorithms much faster than classical computers, such as the Shor algorithm for factorizing numbers.
	+ Qubits and quantum logical gates are the basic elements of quantum computation, which can be used to construct any circuit for quantum algorithms.
	+ Good candidates for realizing qubits are semiconductor quantum dots with controlled electron numbers, which can be encoded using an electron charge or spin.
	+ Spin qubits have longer decoherence times, which are necessary for quantum computation, but require a magnetic field to prepare.
	+ Another concept for encoding the qubit is based on the singlet-triplet states in a double quantum dot, which does not require a magnetic field and can be prepared by electrical control of the exchange interactions.

- Decoherence-free subspace and triangular triple quantum dot (tQD):
	+ Divincenzo et al. suggested building the qubit in a more complex system, namely in three coherently coupled quantum dots (tQD), which can be encoded in the doublet subspace and controlled by exchange interactions.
	+ This subspace is a decoherence-free subspace (DFS), which is immune to decoherence processes, and the exchange interactions can be controlled purely electrically by gate potentials, providing much faster operations.
	+ In the tQD system, more than one exchange interaction between the spins can be modified, allowing for full unitary rotation of the qubit states, and the energy spectrum is more complicated, providing operations on more states compared to the two spin system.
