• Nasopharyngeal bursitis:
   • Originates from the area of communication between the notochord and the foregut.
   • Believed to be a remnant of embryonic communication that normally disappears during fetal development.
   • Can develop into cystic or crust types of nasopharyngeal bursitis.

• Cystic type:
   • Occurs when the embryonic remnant becomes obstructed.
   • More common and should be part of the differential diagnosis of nasopharyngeal abscesses and cysts.
   • Symptoms include space-occupying lesion or rhinitis.

• Crust type:
   • Occurs when crusts adhere to the orifice without obstruction.
   • Crust sheds periodically from the nasopharynx, causing an offensive smell and unpleasant taste.
   • No single report has estimated its true incidence or characterized its symptoms.

• Clinicoanatomical audit findings:
   • Six patients diagnosed with nasopharyngeal bursitis over two years.
   • Equal incidence of cystic and crust types.
   • Patients who underwent surgery had a complete recovery with no recurrence.
   • Endoscopic examination and radiologic investigation are useful in diagnosis.
   • Combined endoscopic endonasal and transoral approach with electrocauterization is a minimally invasive and effective treatment.

* Melanoma skin cancer incidence has been increasing, with an estimated 76,250 new cases and 9,180 deaths in the USA in 2012.
* Australia has one of the highest skin cancer rates, with over 1,890 melanoma-related deaths annually.
* Early diagnosis of melanoma is crucial, and dermoscopy is a noninvasive diagnostic technique that aids in visualizing morphological features not discernible by the naked eye.
* Different dermoscopy techniques, such as Solar Scan, Epiluminescence Microscopy (ELM), Cross-Polarization Epiluminescence (XLM), and Side Transillumination (TLM), can enhance morphological details.
* Dermoscopy improves diagnostic sensitivity by 10-30% but may lower diagnostic accuracy in inexperienced dermatologists.
* Scoring systems and algorithms like the ABCD-E rule, Seven-Point Checklist, Three-Point Checklist, and Menzies method have been proposed to assist less experienced clinicians.
* Automated analysis of digitized images obtained by ELM techniques has gained interest to differentiate early melanoma from benign skin lesions.
* Computational intelligence methods can help physicians and dermatologists in faster data processing for better and more reliable diagnoses.
* Various border detection, feature extraction, selection, and classification algorithms have been reported in the literature for automated classification of pigmented skin lesion images.
* A comprehensive up-to-date review of automatic diagnostic models for skin lesions is not available, and continuous emergence of new classification algorithms and techniques necessitates such a review.

• Laparoscopic cholecystectomy has significant advantages over traditional open cholecystectomy, with similar morbidity and mortality rates.
• The treatment costs for cholelithiasis are over $5 billion per year in the US, with laparoscopic cholecystectomy being more cost-effective due to reduced disability and income loss.
• However, charges for laparoscopic cholecystectomy often exceed those of open cholecystectomy, which is surprising since open cholecystectomy requires more resources and has a longer recovery time.
• A study of 70 cholecystectomy patients found that the average charge for converted laparoscopic cholecystectomies was $19,922, while open cholecystectomies cost an average of $13,042.
• Decision tree analysis showed that open cholecystectomy was more cost-effective than laparoscopic cholecystectomy, but if charges could be reduced to certain levels, laparoscopic cholecystectomy could become cost-effective.
• Reusable instruments and advanced laparoscopic skills could help reduce the charge for laparoscopy and make laparoscopic cholecystectomy more cost-effective.
• Managed care contractors prefer open cholecystectomy for all patients with cholecystitis, but most patients would not enroll in a health plan or go to a hospital that does not provide laparoscopic cholecystectomy.
• Sensitivity analysis shows that if the conversion rate equals 5%, a charge of less than $12,679.90 would be needed to make laparoscopic cholecystectomy cost-effective.
• Health care payers should evaluate charge data for each hospital before contracting for medical services, especially for laparoscopic cholecystectomy, which is in high demand.
• Hospitals and health care providers must evaluate their procedures to inform health care providers that they are cost-efficient and compete for contracts by offering validated cost efficiencies.

• Chondroblastoma is a rare bone tumor affecting the epiphyseal regions of tubular bones, especially tibia, femur, and humerus.
• In the head and neck region, it typically occurs in the temporal bone or temporomandibular joint, resulting in various symptoms such as occlusal abnormalities, trismus, clicking of the TMJ, hearing impairments, dizziness, and otorrhea.
• Malignant changes in chondroblastoma are rare but can occur after irradiation, making radiation therapy not a viable option.
• Complete surgical removal is advisable for curative treatment, but chondroblastoma in the temporal bone has unusual histological features making diagnosis difficult and incomplete resection risking recurrence.
• A case of chondroblastoma in the temporal bone is presented, initially misdiagnosed due to relying on imaging analysis without careful MRI/CT scanning analysis or histopathologic examination.
• The patient, a 41-year-old male, was initially diagnosed with TMJ disorder and underwent several attempts at antibiotic therapy and treatment for eustachian tube blockage, but symptoms were unresponsive.
• After 2 years, endoscopic surgery and further attempts to correct malocclusion for TMJ disorder showed no significant improvement.
• Re-examination of CT scan and pathologic examination revealed the presence of a giant cell tumor in the temporal bone, and the patient consulted for persistent restriction of mouth opening, hearing loss, and dizziness.
• The study emphasizes the importance of accurate diagnosis and suitable surgical procedures for maintaining postoperative functionality in chondroblastoma.

- **Subclinical Hypothyroidism (SCH) and its Association with Adverse Health Outcomes:**
	+ SCH is associated with an increased risk of developing a wide range of adverse health outcomes, including cardiovascular disease (CVD) and mortality.
	+ Understanding the prevalence and risk factors of SCH could aid in the prevention of CVD in this population.

- **Treatment of SCH and the Trust Study:**
	+ The decision to treat or not treat an SCH patient is currently based on clinical judgment, clinical practice guidelines, and expert opinion.
	+ The Trust Study, a multicenter, double-blinded, placebo-controlled randomized trial, aims to assess the multimodal effects of thyroid hormone replacement in 3,000 adults 65 years of age and older with persistent SCH. This study will evaluate clinical outcomes, such as CV events, disease-specific and health-related quality of life, muscle function, and cognitive function, and may help clarify the populations that may benefit from t4 replacement.

- Study of patients with stool specimens submitted for C. difficile-associated diarrhea (CDAD) diagnosis using enzyme immunoassay (EIA)
  - Divided patients into three groups based on EIA results: toxin-positive stool, toxin-negative stool/toxin-positive isolates, and dual toxin-negative stool and isolates

- Clinical characteristics and diarrhea duration
  - No significant differences in number of comorbidities, malignant tumors, recent history of transplant, or use of tube feeding
  - Significant difference in mean diarrhea duration between toxin-positive stool group (10.6 days) and toxin-negative stool specimens (5.6 days)

- Treatment for CDAD
  - Significant difference in the proportion of patients receiving vancomycin or metronidazole treatment among the three groups
  - Fewer patients in the discrepant negative/positive group received treatment, but diarrhea duration tended to be shorter

- Diagnosis and treatment requirements
  - Similar rates of gdh positivity in both toxin-positive and toxin-negative patients
  - Patients with toxin-negative stool specimens had shorter symptom duration and milder symptoms

- Antimicrobial drug use
  - No significant differences in antimicrobial drug use within the 30 days prior to diarrhea onset among the three groups
  - No clear correlation between type of antimicrobial drug administered and the presence of toxins

- EIA vs. PCR for toxin detection
  - EIA directly measures toxin proteins, while PCR detects the presence of bacteria with toxin genes
  - EIA has high positive predictive value, making it an important test in determining treatment approach

- Limitations and recommendations
  - Retrospective study with small sample size and absence of molecular biological testing
  - Further large number analysis required to determine bacterial genetic characteristics

• Brooke-Spiegler Syndrome (BSS) is a rare genodermatosis characterized by the progressive formation of adnexal skin tumors, including trichoepitheliomas, cylindromas, and spiradenomas.
• It is caused by mutations in the tumor suppressor gene CYLD on chromosome 16q12q13.
• A case of BSS in a 71-year-old woman with multiple skin-colored or erythematous papules on her scalp and forehead was studied.
• Histopathological diagnosis confirmed spiradenomas and one cylindroma.
• The patient's family history and physical examination of her daughters suggested autosomal dominant inheritance.
• Genetic testing revealed a heterozygous mutation c. 1628_1629delct in the patient and her two affected daughters.
• The mutation is associated with BSS, and its phenotypic expression varies, including multiple familial trichoepithelioma and familial cylindromatosis.
• Malignant spiradenoma is a very aggressive neoplasm, and periodic follow-up of patients is necessary.

* Biological scaffold materials derived from dermis, pericardium, and small intestine submucosa of human, bovine, and porcine origin have been used in soft tissue repair applications.
	+ These scaffolds are useful in contaminated settings due to their rapid revascularization and clearance of bacteria.
* Early designs of absorbable polymer scaffolds include Dexon and Vicryl, which are comprised of polyglycolic acid (PGA) and a copolymer of glycolide and lactide, respectively.
	+ Dexon degrades in vivo via hydrolysis and is fully resorbed in approximately 60-90 days, while Vicryl loses 77% of its strength in the first 14 days and is fully resorbed in approximately 60-90 days.
* Both Dexon and Vicryl scaffolds lose mechanical strength and are resorbed fairly quickly, making them less than ideal for hernia repair applications.
	+ More recent absorbable scaffold designs utilize long-lasting polymers that degrade more slowly.
* Gore Bio-A, Tigr Matrix, and Phasix Mesh are examples of newer absorbable scaffolds that degrade in vivo through both hydrolytic and enzymatic mechanisms.
	+ These scaffolds have been evaluated in animal studies and clinical trials for various surgical applications, with promising outcomes.
* Phasix Mesh is a fully resorbable polymer monofilament that is knitted into a flat sheet configuration, while the P4HB plug is preformed into a three-dimensional shape.
	+ Both have been evaluated in a porcine model to determine their mechanical properties, resorption profile, and histological characteristics when utilized to bridge a surgical defect.
* Mechanical testing revealed that the burst strength and relative stiffness of the Phasix Mesh and P4HB plug repaired sites were similar to each other at all time points evaluated.
	+ Sites repaired with these materials also exhibited significantly greater burst strength and relative stiffness compared to the native abdominal wall.
* Gel permeation chromatography was conducted to quantify the molecular weight of the P4HB material remaining at the repair

	+ The Xpert Vana/Vanb assay was implemented in a laboratory serving a population of 800,000 inhabitants in Denmark.
	+ The assay is a fully automated system that provides DNA extraction and real-time PCR results within an hour.

- **Diagnostic Accuracy and Impact on Infection Control**:
	+ The diagnostic accuracy of the Xpert Vana/Vanb assay was evaluated, and it was found to have a sensitivity of 87.1% and specificity of 99.7% for the Vana gene.
	+ The implementation of the assay led to a saving of 141 isolation days and 292 transmission risk days.

- **Discordant Results and Investigation**:
	+ Of the 1099 samples with available pcr and culture results, only 29 showed discordant results.
	+ Investigation of vanA pcr-positive, culture-negative samples led to the isolation of phenotypically vancomycin-susceptible, but vanA pcr-positive E. faecium.

- **Strengths and Limitations**:
	+ The study's strengths include the large sample size and the prospective and thorough comparison of the Xpert Vana/Vanb assay with the selective culture method.
	+ A systematic study of genetically diverse strains would be necessary to conclude on the generalizability of the results.

• Hyperglycaemia persisted throughout the study period and was 306 ± 18 mg/dl at four weeks in stz-treated animals compared to 96 ± 4 mg/dl in the nondiabetic (control) animals.

* Modern nasal surgery aims to improve both the cosmetic appearance and natural functions of the nose
* Acoustic rhinometry is a common method used to measure nasal cavity geometry by analyzing reflected acoustic impulses
* In a study of healthy Iranian volunteers who underwent cosmetic rhinoplasty, acoustic rhinometry was used to evaluate changes in nasal dimensions before and after surgery
* The study found that the minimum cross-sectional area (MCA) and volume of the nasal cavity decreased significantly after surgery, while the distance to the minimum cross-sectional areas (d1 and d2) did not change significantly
* The study also found that patients who underwent rhinoplasty plus septoplasty experienced more increase in MCA1 and less constriction in MCA2 postoperatively compared to patients who underwent rhinoplasty alone
* Placing a columellar strut in patients who underwent rhinoplasty plus septoplasty had a significant effect on MCA1 and MCA2 levels, while in patients who underwent rhinoplasty alone, placing a columellar strut caused a greater amount of increase in MCA1
* Regression analysis revealed no fixed significant effect for septoplasty, osteotomy, and placing a columellar strut on the difference after surgery in MCA1, MCA2, and v
* The study suggests that surgeons should be aware of common patterns of change in nose geometry, take care in intervening in the region of the second constriction, perform osteotomy to help patients maintain nasal patency, and consider placing a strut in most cases

• Cardiovascular disease (CVD) is the leading cause of mortality in many developed nations, accounting for 30% of all deaths, with its incidence still increasing.
• Ongoing research aims to investigate and prevent the early development of CVD risk factors, such as atherosclerosis, hypertension, dyslipidemia, chronic inflammation, and insulin resistance.
• N-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids (n-3 PUFAs) have beneficial effects on CVD, with lipid-lowering, anti-inflammatory, antithrombotic, antiatherosclerotic, and antiarrhythmogenic properties.
• Low-grade chronic inflammation is a prominent process in atherosclerosis and coronary heart disease development, and n-3 PUFAs can modulate this inflammatory response.
• There are two main types of PUFAs: omega-3 (n-3) and omega-6 (n-6) fatty acids, with different locations of the last double bond. The human body can produce all fatty acids except for linoleic acid (LA) and alpha-linolenic acid (ALA), which are essential fatty acids.
• The conversion of ALA to longer-chain n-3 PUFAs, such as EPA and DHA, is limited in humans, making dietary intake crucial for maintaining tissue and circulating EPAs and DHAs.
• Fish is the primary food source of long-chain n-3 PUFAs, while ALA is mainly found in seeds, nuts, and their oils. Different sources of n-3 PUFAs may have specific effects on cardiovascular risk markers.
• In atherosclerosis, endothelial cells' balance between pro- and anti-inflammatory molecules is disrupted, leading to increased production of proinflammatory cytokines, oxidative stress, and further progression of the disease.
• N-3 PUFAs and their eicosanoid derivatives can modulate the inflammatory response, and a balanced intake of ALA and LA or their longer-chain products is required for optimal cardiovascular health.

• Rudolf Virchow's contributions include the idea that cancer arises from chronic irritation or inflammation
• Pelayo Correa's model proposes a stepwise process of gastric cancer development beginning with chronic atrophic gastritis
• Correa initially thought environmental factors, such as diet, were responsible for promoting gastric mutagenesis
• In 1988, Correa briefly discussed a possible role for Campylobacter pylori in the initiation of the disease
• Robin Warren and Barry Marshall discovered H. pylori's role in gastritis and ulcer disease
• Initial investigations into a possible association of H. pylori with gastric cancer provided weak evidence
• More convincing evidence came from cohort studies showing prior H. pylori infection was significantly more common in those who subsequently developed gastric cancer
• Subsequent research has confirmed and expanded upon the early epidemiologic studies, with key additional clinical findings

• Cardia cancers are not associated strongly with H. pylori infection
• H. pylori is just as great a risk factor for the pathway leading to diffuse-type gastric cancer
• Measuring H. pylori exposure by ELISA underestimates prior exposure and attributable risk
• Caga-positive H. pylori strains increase the risk of gastric cancer to a greater extent
• H. pylori eradication can reduce the risk of developing gastric cancer
• A prolonged observational study showed h pylori-infected patients had a higher rate of progression to gastric cancer
• Ethical issues hampered the completion of a definitive study of h pylori's role in gastric cancer
• Recent meta-analyses indicate h pylori eradication decreases the risk of gastric cancer development by approximately 40% in studies of primary prevention and by 54% as a tertiary prevention strategy
• The benefit of h pylori eradication is most evident in subjects living in areas with the highest gastric cancer prevalence

• Study comparing functional and anatomical outcomes of bevacizumab and ranibizumab therapy in Turkish patients with neovascular age-related macular degeneration (NAMD)
• Two groups of patients, one treated with bevacizumab and the other with ranibizumab, had similar general characteristics
• Both groups showed significant improvement in mean best-corrected visual acuity (BCVA) and central retinal thickness (CRT) compared to baseline
• No statistically significant difference in change in BCVA and CRT between the two groups at all time points
• Mean number of injections and intraocular pressure (IOP) were similar between the two groups, and no serious ocular or systemic complications were observed

• Previous clinical studies have reported similar improvements in visual and anatomical outcomes with bevacizumab and ranibizumab
• Short-term efficacy and safety study found similar improvements in visual and anatomical outcomes one month after intravitreal injection
• Retrospective study with 371 NAMD patients found no statistical difference in visual acuity changes between bevacizumab and ranibizumab groups after a median follow-up time of 12 months

• Visual acuity outcomes were similar between the two drugs, and both were effective in stabilizing visual acuity in NAMD patients after 12 months of follow-up
• Mean injection numbers at month 12 were similar between the two groups in the study, but a retrospective study reported greater mean visual acuity improvement in the ranibizumab group than the bevacizumab group

• CATT study found no significant difference between the two drugs in regards to visual acuity and anatomical outcomes and the mean injection numbers at first year
• Two-year results of the study showed similar visual and anatomical outcomes, but the mean gain in visual acuity was greater in monthly groups than as-needed groups
• Study addressed safety issue and adverse events between the two drugs, with a greater rate of serious adverse events in the bevacizumab groups than the ranibizumab groups with a cumulative risk ratio of 1.30, but not statistically significant

- **Immunotherapy approaches for cancer treatment:**
  * Many new immunotherapy approaches have entered clinical development in the last two decades due to the increased understanding of the immune system's mechanisms.
  * Some agents have been approved for standard clinical use, such as infusional cytokine therapies, intravesical BCG therapy, and an active cellular therapy targeting prostatic acid phosphatase for advanced metastatic prostate cancer.
  * Other agents, like a monoclonal antibody targeting a T-cell checkpoint inhibitor targeting CTLA-4 for advanced melanoma, have demonstrated benefit in large clinical trials and are awaiting approval.

- **Challenges in evaluating immunotherapy agents:**
  * Traditional paradigms for clinical development may not be suitable for evaluating these agents, especially when used in combination with other immune-activating or conventional therapies.
  * Identifying markers of biological response, ideally associated with clinical outcome, is essential for evaluating the biological effect of these agents used in combination.

- **Use of biomarkers in immunotherapy research:**
  * Antigen-specific vaccines have used immune responses to the target antigen as a biomarker of immunological efficacy, but there are few instances where target antigen immune response has been associated with clinical benefit.
  * For broadly active immune modulating agents, appropriate biomarkers of response have been more elusive, with studies seeking to identify potential biomarkers such as amplification of other T-cell costimulatory molecules or antibodies to defined antigenic tumor-associated proteins.

- **Machine learning in biomarker identification:**
  * The paper explores the use of machine-learned Bayesian belief networks (ML-BBNs) as a method for identifying potentially promising biomarkers and potential biomarker networks.
  * The study aimed to train several ML-BBNs to identify promising biomarkers and then use these networks to select a subset of features to train a network of immune biomarkers as they related to observed declines in serum prostate-specific antigen (PSA).
</summary>

• In vivo study using Merino ewe as animal model
• Devices implanted in left and right hind limbs for comparison

• Devices composed of microboard, ultra-low power 16-bit microcontroller, lithium battery, encapsulated in PMMA, and set of six actuators
• Actuators made of PVDF and silver electrodes, electrically insulated by dip-coating
• Each actuator measures 15 mm width and 40 mm length, with an active area of 12 31 mm
• Actuator device programmed to apply a 5 V square wave of 1 Hz and 3 Hz for 15 minutes at each frequency, once every 24 hours

• Actuator device implanted in the left hind limb
• Control device implanted in the right hind limb
• Incisions closed routinely with a continuous-pattern suture in the retinaculum and fascia, and in the skin
• Postoperative X-ray images obtained 30 days after implantation
• Bone samples cut transversally to the long axis of the bone, each including a piezoelectric film and the surrounding bone
• Undecalcified bone samples of each of the implants included in resin according to the manufacturer's instructions
• Sections cut with a saw microtome parallel to the piezoelectric film long axis
• Sections appropriately processed for routine staining, mounted for fluorescence microscopy

• Total bone area, immature bone area, and mature bone area measured using SigmaScanPro 5
• Results determined for each piezoelectric film in the pre-determined areas z1 to z4
• Normal distribution of the results verified using the Kolmogorov-Smirnov test
• Homogeneity of variance assessed through the Levene test
• Differences between groups tested using one-way anova (at a 0.05 level)

- Experiment setup and animal model
	+ Male Wistar rats (10 weeks old) were used in the experiment.
	+ Rats were divided into weight-bearing (WB) and non-weight-bearing (NWB) groups.
	+ Both groups received LPS and methylprednisolone injections to induce non-traumatic osteonecrosis of the femoral head (ONFH).
	+ WB rats were allowed to walk and move freely, while NWB rats had their hindlimbs unloaded using a tail suspension system.

- Observation of ONFH
	+ ONFH was observed in 63.6% of WB rats and 54.5% of NWB rats.
	+ No significant difference was found between the two groups (p = 0.66).
	+ Empty lacunae and decreased hematopoietic cells were observed in the femoral head of both WB and NWB rats with ONFH.
	+ No humeral head ONFH was observed in any of the rats.

- Comparison of femoral and humeral heads
	+ Both WB and NWB rats showed diffuse presence of empty lacunae in the bone trabeculae of the femoral head.
	+ The bone marrow cell necrosis was also observed in most areas of the femoral head in both groups.
	+ The humeral head of WB rats showed normal trabeculae and haematopoietic and fat cells.
	+ The humeral head of NWB rats showed a large number of haematopoietic cells but few fat cells compared to WB rats.

- Implications and conclusions
	+ The study confirmed that weight bearing does not contribute to the development of non-traumatic ONFH in rats.
	+ The rat model may help elucidate the pathogenesis of ONFH and devise a prevention strategy, but may not be useful for observing the mechanism of femoral head collapse.
	+ The aetiology, pathogenesis, and prognosis of non-traumatic ONFH remain unclear.

  * Health systems hierarchies

  * Systemic exclusion of nurses from senior leadership positions

- **Nursing professional factors hindering nurses' participation in policy processes**
  * Inadequate knowledge and skills required to contribute to policy processes
  * Lack of policy content in nursing training curricula
  * Inadequate advocacy, research, and political skills
  * Nursing leadership viewed as internal to the nursing profession
  * Nurses working in isolation from other professionals in the system

• • Major previous reports of brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) abnormalities related to CAH include white matter hyperintensities or leukoencephalopathy.

• • Exogenous glucocorticoids may alter the process of neuronal maturation and myelination by inhibiting the differentiation of oligodendrocyte precursors.

• Brain structures susceptible to the effects of excess glucocorticoids and androgens:

• • The hippocampus and the amygdala have many androgen and glucocorticoid receptors and are particularly susceptible to the effects of excess glucocorticoids.
• • Alterations in amygdala function have been implicated in the pathophysiological characteristics of anxiety and depressive disorders in both adults and children.

• Cognitive impairment and hippocampal abnormalities in CAH patients:

• • Studies have reported discrepant findings on cognitive function in CAH patients.
• • The present study showed temporal lobe atrophy in one patient and hippocampal dysgenesis in two patients, the first one demonstrating hippocampal abnormalities on MR imaging in patients with CAH.

- The use of heart rate monitors (HRMs) in sports and sports science has been widespread over the last 25 years.
	+ Handy HRMs with the size of a watch and flexible chest belts with electrodes to transmit signals wirelessly to the watch have made heart rate measurement an easily accessible and valuable tool.
	+ The validity and reliability of these tools have been shown to be high compared to ECG measurements for both heart rate (HR) and heart rate variability (HRV).
	+ Recent technical development has focused on real-time monitoring instead of post-exercise evaluation of recorded data.
- Four commercially available HRMS were tested in a field test: Polar Team Pro, Acentas Team Monitoring System, Suunto Pro Team Pack, and Activio Sport System.
	+ All systems allow direct and real-time monitoring of several individuals at the same time.
	+ Data are transmitted wirelessly to a receiver which is connected with a standard laptop with relevant software.
	+ A direct comparison of these systems and validity of recorded data are missing in literature.
- A total of 12 active people participated in the study, ten of whom conducted an online field test during a real football match.
	+ The following four commercially available systems were used for all tests: Polar Team Pro, Acentas Team Monitoring System, Suunto Pro Team Pack, and Activio Sport System.
	+ A quality rating system was used to evaluate the systems in three main categories: measurement, software, and hardware.
	+ The core area of the study focused on the adequate online measurement of the heart rate.
- The rating system was set in favour of the measurement which was represented by 200 scores of maximal 500.
	+ The latter 300 were equally divided on quality of the hardware and the usability of the software.
	+ Subcategories were weighted subjectively by the authors in consideration of heart rate monitoring of team sports including the monitoring of 10 or more subjects in parallel.
	+ The remaining categories were judged once by an experienced person.
- Wearing comfort of the chest belts was evaluated via a short anonymous questionnaire which all 12 participants had to complete directly after wearing.
	+ The questionnaire contained five questions about the handling and individual fitting of the chest belts.

- McCulloch and Till proposed 3 functional characteristics of stem cells in the 1960s.
  * Self-renewal: the ability to make identical copies of themselves.
  * Proliferation: the ability to extensively divide and grow.
  * Multipotency: the ability to give rise to various cell types.
- Stem cells in the lung are difficult to identify due to the low turnover rate of lung epithelia.
  * Populations of stem cells have been identified in the lung through their role in injury response.
  * The functional tenets of stem cell behavior (self-renewal, proliferation, and multipotency) have been observed in these cells.
- The earliest stages of lung malignancies may be related to a deregulation of the stem cell-based repair mechanism.
- The airway progresses from proximal to distal with different types of epithelium.
  * Cells capable of stem-like behavior in response to airway injury are present throughout the airway.
  * In proximal airways, tracheal basal cells expressing keratin-5 (k5) or keratin-14 (k14) have stem cell-like properties.
  * Squamous cell carcinoma frequently arises from the more proximal tracheobronchial airways and may be related to k5 stem cells.
- In middle airways, mature clara cells can proliferate into phenotypically diverse progeny and repair the airway after injury.
  * Clara-cell secretory protein (CCSP)-positive cells located within neuroepithelial bodies (NEB) can repopulate the middle airways after naphthalene injury.
  * Small cell lung carcinomas frequently arise in the mid-level bronchioles and contain fractions of cells expressing mid-airway stem cell subpopulations.
- The cell surface markers CD44 and multidrug resistance 1 (MDR1) have been identified in small cell lung carcinoma cell lines.
  * Cells expressing CD44 have been implicated in lung cancer progression and metastasis by the epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EMT).

• The Iberian wall lizard, Podarcis hispanica, is a small lizard found in the Iberian Peninsula, with molecular and morphological studies suggesting it is paraphyletic and forms a species complex.

• A study was conducted to explore the role of chemical sexual signals in interpopulational recognition between five distinct populations of Iberian wall lizards in central Spain. The study found that:

- The lizards from different populations have distinct morphological characteristics and chemical compounds in their femoral gland secretions.
- Males from each population secreted a unique mixture of compounds used as sexual signals.
- Tongue-flick tests showed that these differences resulted in differential chemosensory recognition between some populations.
- The results suggested that there could be premating reproductive isolation between some, but not all, populations of this lizard.

</summary>

• The study found that there are morphological differences between lizards from the southern and northern populations. The lizards from the northern populations (fuenfra and golondrina) were larger, heavier, and had larger, more robust heads than the lizards from the southern populations (aranjuez and belmonte). These differences could be explained by the different contrasting environments where these populations live, with the northern mountains having cold temperatures, high humidity, and high altitude, and the southern plains having hot temperatures, dry conditions, and low altitude.

• The study also found that there are differences in the number of femoral pores and blue spots between the populations. Males from the northern populations have more femoral pores and less blue spots than males from the southern populations. These differences suggest that the importance of chemical and visual signals may differ between populations, with a higher number of femoral pores being related to a higher production of chemical secretions, and a larger number of blue spots representing a higher use of visual signals. The relative importance of these two sensory modes may be explained by the effectiveness of these two types of communication in different environments.

<summary>

• The scientific activity of a research group is often measured through published papers, which are validated and legitimized by their peers.
• These papers can also serve as indicators of the development of their scientific knowledge in their area of research.
• Major international databases that contain publications from scientific journals in the area of health science include Medline/Pubmed, Web of Science, Embase, and Current Contents.
• In Brazil, the main databases are Lilacs and Scielo, which allows free access to full texts of Brazilian, Latin American and Caribbean scientific literature.
• Medline/Pubmed is the most often searched database due to its free access and large number of titles.
• The recovery of articles and citations can be difficult due to the non-standardized ways that authors and institutions can be entered in databases.
• The journals selected for publication reflect the level of productivity of a research group and are evaluated according to certain bibliometric indicators, such as the Impact Factor (IF).
• Few Brazilian journals have IFs, but this number has recently increased.
• The present investigation analyzed the scientific production of full professors at the Universidade de São Paulo, Faculdade de Medicina between 2001 and 2006.

• There were 66 full professors, with 86.4% being males and 13.6% being females.
• 36.4% of the professors were teaching full-time, 60.6% were working intermediate shifts, and only 3% were working partial shifts.
• The survey revealed 1,960 bibliographic records published in 630 international and national scientific journals.
• There was a gradual growth in the scientific production of the researchers during these years, with an average publication rate of five articles per year by each professor.
• Only 2% of the published articles had the professors as sole authors, and 5% had them as first authors.
• The professors were co-authors for the majority of publications, which included partnerships with other researchers from the institution.
• 47.7% of the articles were printed in journals with IFs between 1 and 5.
• 20% of the articles were published in four journals with assigned IFs in Brazil.

• Rubella infection during early pregnancy has a 90% chance of passing through the placenta to the fetus, potentially causing congenital rubella syndrome (CRS).
• Vaccination of susceptible individuals can prevent the disease and its complications. The primary purpose of rubella vaccination is to prevent CRS, which affects an estimated 110,000 infants each year in developing countries.
• The rubella vaccine is derived from the Ra27/3 virus strain and is the most commonly used vaccine globally. It provides more immunity and has a similar immune response to natural infection compared to other vaccines.
• In Iran, the rubella and mumps vaccines were added to the national vaccination plan in 2003, resulting in a significant decrease in measles and rubella cases.
• A study in Kermanshah, Iran, compared the susceptibility and resistance of kermanshahi girls at marriage before and after mass rubella vaccination. The results showed a significant increase in immunity against rubella in vaccinated girls compared to unvaccinated girls.

</summary>

• Whole mount in situ hybridization (WISH) has been advanced by the use of cell type specific molecular markers, enabling the description and analysis of developmental morphogenesis in various biological systems.
• Gene-specific RNA probes are widely used in WISH for visualizing gene expression patterns, providing valuable information about the role of specific genes during development and the positioning and movement of particular cell types at different stages.
• Fluorescent methods for detecting transcripts have several advantages over chromogenic methods, including higher quality three-dimensional imaging, multiplexing different RNA species, and covisualization of RNA with proteins. However, the use of fluorescent methods for WISH is limited by high endogenous background fluorescence and the limited brightness and photostability of organic fluorophores.
• Quantum dots (QDs), a new type of inorganic fluorophore, have ideal optical properties for use in biology, including strong fluorescent signal emission, wide excitation spectra, narrow and tunable emission spectra, large separation between the excitation and emission, and resistance to photobleaching. QDs have been used successfully for in situ hybridization in clinical biopsies for the detection of multiple mRNAs with successful conjugation to oligonucleotide probes.
• The use of QDs for WISH in xenopus embryos, one of the most highly autofluorescent vertebrate developmental organisms, suggests that QD whole-mount in situs will find successful applications in most developmental models.

• Study on aspirin therapy for cardiovascular disease (CVD) prevention in the United States:

- Examines the relationship between physician recommendations for aspirin therapy and CVD risk based on the Framingham Risk Score (FRS)
- Analyzes data from the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) for the years 2011-2012
- Finds that recommendations for aspirin for CVD prevention do not match up to objectively computed future risk
- Highlights the need for improved clinical decision support to aid in accurate decisions for aspirin therapy

• Factors associated with physician recommendations for aspirin therapy:

- Among all primary prevention patients, education level, insurance status, and having a regular source of care were predictive of receiving a recommendation for aspirin for CVD prevention
- Among high-risk individuals, age, health insurance, and being of Asian/other descent were predictive of receiving a recommendation for aspirin for CVD prevention
- Among low-risk individuals, age, health insurance status, education level, and obesity status were all predictive of receiving a recommendation for aspirin therapy

• Access to care and insurance status impact aspirin recommendations and usage:

- Lack of health insurance can be a significant barrier to accessing health care, including preventive services
- Previous research has found no relationship between insurance status and aspirin use among patients who accessed clinical preventive services
- The present results suggest that access to care may play a role in recommendations for the advice of aspirin for CVD prevention, and the use of it by patients

• Limitations of the study:

- Self-reported data on physician recommendations and other variables may be unreliable
- The study only examines adults age 40 and over, and there could be important patterns of use among younger individuals
- The study does not know how many respondents were recommended to take aspirin for heart attack or stroke prevention versus for cancer prevention
- The study did not control for use of warfarin or other anticoagulant/antiplatelet therapy among respondents
- The available data from NHANES do not allow for elucidation of the role of gastrointestinal bleeding risk in the decision of physicians to recommend aspirin

• The Patient-Centered Medical Home (PCMH) model is an extension of Edward Wagner's Chronic Care Model (CCM), aiming to provide quality, coordinated, and cost-effective care to patients.
• Over 1,500 sites and 7,700 clinicians across the US have completed the NCQA recognition process and are functioning as PCMHs.
• The transition process into PCMH can be difficult, with common concerns including promoting physician buy-in, changing office culture, care coordination, staffing and space allocations, and leveraging electronic medical records.
• To become recognized as a PCMH by the NCQA, a practice must provide documentation of its guidelines for implementation and adhere to PCMH principles while accounting for its patient panels, location, and financial resources.
• The PCMH model emphasizes team-based care, which requires staff to address patient treatment decisions collectively and introduce previsit meetings to allocate resources and ensure adequate health maintenance and chronic care management.
• The transformation of a primary care practice into a PCMH requires significant changes in office culture, including new experiences for current members, additional training for nurses and front office staff, and sophisticated decision-making skills for clerical and clinical staff members.

• Based on a meta-analysis of six randomized controlled trials

• Primary outcomes
• Survival rate
• • No significant difference in survival rate at hospital discharge between treatment and control groups
• • Significant difference in survival rate after 6 months in favor of treatment group
• Neurological function
• • No significant difference in neurological function at hospital discharge between treatment and control groups
• • Significant difference in neurological function after 6 months in favor of treatment group

• Adverse events
• • Mild hypothermia does not influence the incidence of rearrest
• • No significant difference in other adverse events between treatment and control groups

• Possible reasons for no improvement in survival rate and neurological function at hospital discharge
• • Whole-body hypothermia influences all organ systems and may have side effects
• • Combination hypothermia with other drugs may bring about unknown influences
• • Hypothermia revives neurons is a long and slow process

• Advantages of mild hypothermia
• • Reduces cerebral oxygen consumption and energy metabolism
• • Reduces reactive oxygen species generation and release of excitatory amino acids
• • Preserves the integrity of the blood-brain barrier and regulates the gene expression of inflammatory protein and apoptotic proteins

• Limitations of the meta-analysis
• • Inadequate number of trials and study size
• • Clinical and methodological heterogeneity

• Conclusion
• • Mild hypothermia cannot improve survival rate and neurological function of patients at hospital discharge
• • Mild hypothermia improves prognosis of patients and does not influence the incidence of adverse events compared with the control group

* A male factor is responsible for around 40% of marital infertility.
* Varicocele is a condition characterized by enlargement and elongation of the pampiniform plexus, venous convolution, and sinus formation with backflow.
* The left testicular vein runs vertically and joins the left renal vein opposite the origin of the lower adrenal vein, leading to blood turbulence and retrograde flow of renal metabolites and adrenal hormones to the testis.
* Elevated hydrostatic pressure within the testicular vein results in venous stasis, testicular hyperemia, and compromised testicular oxygen concentration.
* Testicular growth can be arrested in children and adolescents with varicocele due to atrophic changes within convoluted tubules caused by increased scrotal temperature or tissue hypoxia.
* A high-grade varicocele can be detected during a meticulous andrologic examination and confirmed by accessory ultrasound with Doppler examination.
* A palpable varicocele with testicular hypotrophy on the affected side, confirmed by color Doppler, is an indication for surgical repair.
* A retrospective study of 68 adolescents who underwent laparoscopic repair for idiopathic varicocele with testicular hypotrophy showed significant improvement in testicular volume and semen parameters.
* Late diagnosis and treatment of varicocele can result in spermatogenesis disturbances and abnormal concentrations of sex hormones.

• Erectile dysfunction is caused by injury to the cavernosal nerves, which were identified by Walsh and Donker as branching from the pelvic plexus and running as a plexus of small nerves within a neurovascular bundle on the posterolateral border of the prostate. Nerve-sparing radical retropubic prostatectomy has led to improvements in potency rates.

• A study was conducted to describe periprostatic nerve distribution and construct a 3-dimensional model of nerve distribution. The prostate, together with seminal vesicle, bladder, and rectum, was removed en bloc from five adult male human cadavers and stained with anti-s-100 antibody neural stain to delineate the precise location of neural tissue.

• The study found that nerve fibers were distributed evenly around the prostatic capsule, with the exception of the ventral part, which had significantly fewer nerve fibers. The average number of nerve fibers in the ventral part of the prostate was 5.75±1.20, while the average number in the dorsal (rectal) part was 28.50±2.17.

• The three-dimensional model of the periprostatic nerve fibers revealed an almost even distribution and nearly similar thickness of periprostatic nerve fibers on dorsal and both lateral parts. However, the nerve fibers in the ventral part were substantially fewer in number and decreased in thickness.

• Traditionally, it was thought that cavernosal nerves branched from the pelvic plexus and ran as a plexus of small nerves within a prominent cord-like neurovascular bundle on the posterolateral border of the prostate. However, recent studies have challenged this knowledge and shown variations in the distributions of autonomic fibers between different individuals.

• Polyhalite (chemical formula: K2Ca2Mg(SO4)4·2H2O) is a mineral that commonly occurs in sedimentary evaporite successions and in rare cases as a sublimate in volcanic successions. It was first described in a salt mine in Bad Ischl, Austria, and has since been found in many salt deposits worldwide. In evaporites, polyhalite is commonly associated with halite, anhydrite, glauberite, carnallite, kieserite, langbeinite, vanthoffite, chlorides, and sulphides.

• The crystal structure of polyhalite was first determined in samples from Altaussee, Austria, and later confirmed. It can be synthesized in the laboratory under specific conditions. The dehydration temperature of polyhalite has been found to start at 255°C and reach a maximum of 343°C. Substitution of divalent cations by other elements significantly changes dehydration reactions to higher or lower temperatures.

• Polyhalite most commonly forms early-diagenetically by brine-back reactions of K-Mg-SO4 brine with earlier formed gypsum, anhydrite, or glauberite after prolonged contact with the precursor rock. It is stable between room temperature (0-25°C) and 255-343°C and is of secondary origin in alpine salt deposits.

• The alpine polyhalites of the Haselgebirge formation in the Northern Calcareous Alps (NCA) are of secondary origin and formed at ca. 235-210 Ma, ca. 2025 Ma, and with a maximum estimated overburden of approximately 800 m. They are found in tectonic lenses within the protocataclasite to protomylonite matrix and show various fabric types.

	+ Propofol did not affect MDA levels, suggesting that its metabolism is not linked to free radical generation in animal tissues
	+ Propofol increased total cholesterol, triglycerides, and LDL-cholesterol, while decreasing HDL-cholesterol levels
	+ The increased cholesterol level may be due to increased alpha-hydroxyl methyl glutaryl coa reductase activity
	+ The increased triglycerides levels may be due to increased free fatty acid, glycerophosphates, decreased triglycerides lipase activity, or decreased fatty oxidation
	+ Propofol increased hepatic GSH levels and the activities of hepatic glutathione peroxidase and glutathione-S-transferase

- Propofol effects on liver and renal function in rats
	+ Propofol had no adverse effects on hepatic and renal tissues, as indicated by insignificant effects on AST, ALT, and creatinine levels
	+ The increase in total bilirubin levels may be due to increased muscle and heart lesion, as indicated by increased LDH and CK-MB activities

- Propofol effects on antioxidant status in rats
	+ Propofol promotes the antioxidant status of the rats by increasing the levels of reduced glutathione and GSH-dependent enzymes

- Propofol use in patients with cardiovascular or lipid disorders
	+ The use of propofol in patients with cardiovascular or lipid disorders should be carefully reviewed due to its detrimental effect on the lipid profile

* The study evaluates the extrusion of debris after using different finishing files for removing residual root canal fillings.
* The finishing files used are Protaper Next (PTN), Waveone (WO), and Self-Adjusting File (SAF).
* The null hypothesis is that there will be no significant differences in the amount of debris extruded by the three files.
* The study uses the model described by Myers and Montgomery for evaluating apical extrusion of debris.
* The root fillings were removed using Protaper Universal RFS, and then the supplementary files were used to remove the root filling residues.
* The weights of the debris extruded were compared between the control group and the experimental groups.
* The results showed that the WO file used after RFS extruded significantly more debris (27% increase) compared to PTN (19% increase) and SAF (12% increase).
* SAF was associated with the least extrusion of debris among the three experimental groups.
* The study exhibited that debris extruded apically regardless of the retreatment protocol.
* The current study aimed to conclude the debris extrusion using supplementary files after using Protaper Universal RFS.

</summary>

<summary>

• Anesthetizing maxillary teeth:
	• Traditional method: Injection in mucobuccal supraperiosteal fold near apices of teeth
	• Effective for pulpal anesthesia but requires multiple injections and causes lip/facial muscle numbness
	• Other techniques include infraorbital, maxillary, intraosseous, and intraligamentary injections

• Anterior and Middle Superior Alveolar (AMSA) nerve block:
	• Proposed by Friedman and Hochman (1998)
	• Single injection for central incisor to second premolar anesthesia via palatal approach
	• Achieved without lip numbness or facial muscle interference
	• Anesthetizes buccal gingiva, teeth, palatal gingiva/mucosa, and maxillary nerve branches

• Study on AMSA nerve block with conventional syringe:
	• 30 Caucasian patients, average age 22 years old
	• Exclusion criteria: Systemic pathologies, pregnancy, medication use, orthodontic treatment, extractions, prostheses, extensive fillings, or endodontic treatment
	• Patients received AMSA nerve block on one side of maxilla using conventional syringe and 1 ml of lidocaine 2% with epinephrine
	• Teeth tested included maxillary central incisor, lateral incisor, canine, and first and second premolars

• Results of AMSA nerve block study:
	• Anesthetic success rates ranged from 16.7% to 66.6%
	• No patient obtained anesthetic blockade of five experimental teeth
	• Duration of pulpal anesthesia gradually declined during 60 minutes
	• All patients had palatal soft tissue anesthesia, no facial anesthesia

• Considerations for AMSA nerve block:
	• Reduces number of injections and anesthetic solution quantity
	• Ideal for cosmetic dentistry as it doesn't cause lip/facial numbness
	• Low success rates with conventional syringe system compared to computer-controlled systems
	• Anatomical studies

<summary>

• Recent advances in molecular biology and microscopy have improved our understanding of genome folding and its role in gene expression and DNA replication
• The genome is organized hierarchically into chromosome territories, genomic compartments, and topologically associating domains (TADs)
• TADs are stable units of chromosomes that exhibit higher frequency of physical contacts between genes and regulatory regions
• TAD boundaries are enriched for certain features, such as CTCF, cohesin, and histone marks, and serve as barriers to long- and short-range interactions between DNA sequences
• A recent study found that the major ATPase subunit of the SWI/SNF chromatin remodeling complex, Brg1, contributes to TAD boundary strength and affects nucleosome occupancy and higher order chromatin organization
• The study performed RNA-seq, Hi-C, and ChIP-seq in control and Brg1 knockdown mammary epithelial cells to delineate the role of Brg1 in genome architecture
• The results showed that Brg1 regulates the expression of genes related to extracellular matrix and lipid synthesis, and is involved in the differential expression of long non-coding RNAs
</summary>

• Brg1 primarily binds to genic regions (60%) and intergenic peaks include super-enhancers
• Comparison of control and Brg1 knockdown Hi-C data sets revealed that the majority of TAD boundaries were largely overlapping, but more than 10% of the TAD boundaries were unique to either the control or the Brg1 knockdown cells
• The strength of TAD boundaries was significantly reduced in Brg1 knockdown human mammary epithelial cells, resulting in a higher frequency of inter-TAD genomic interactions
• Brg1 loss may disrupt chromatin accessibility and preclude the binding of transcription factors and/or chromatin modifiers at TAD boundaries

• Recent hypotheses suggest that the orderly positioning and occupancy of nucleosomes at TAD boundaries renders the local chromatin less flexible, preventing long-range interactions surpassing the boundary
• The orderly positioning and occupancy of nucleosomes at TAD boundaries may be achieved by enriched CTCF binding

* Study of count data using statistical modeling and Poisson/Negative Binomial distribution
* Poisson regression used for count variables, such as number of failed courses or semesters
* Zero inflated Poisson/Negative Binomial distributions for count variables with an inflation in zero
* Various researches applied Poisson/Negative Binomial regressions, zero inflated Poisson/Negative Binomial regressions
* Iran University of Medical Sciences study applied Poisson/Negative Binomial regressions with zero inflated for number of failed courses and semesters
* Predictor variables include educational and demographic factors affecting academic performance
* Data collected from university education file and deputy head of university in students affairs
* Descriptive statistics and zero inflated Poisson/Negative Binomial regression used for data analysis
* Results showed that university average and quota system have inverse relationship with failed semesters
* Increase in university average and change from other quota system to free quota system decreases failed semesters

> * In Poisson regression for number of failed courses, increase in university average decreases logarithm of number of failed courses
> * In regression of failed semesters, university average has negative relationship with number of failed semesters
> * With change of quota system to free quota system, expected logarithm of number of failed semesters decreases
> * Increase in number of failed courses decreases logarithm odd of inflated zero
> * Quota system is a factor that decreases failed semesters
> * Increase in number of failed courses results in number of failed semesters
> * University average and bachelor/master educational levels have negative relationship with number of failed courses
> * Gender and marital status have inverse/positive relationship with number of failed courses
> * In Negative Binomial regression, bachelor level and faculties of management and rehabilitation cause increase in number of failed courses
> * Increase in failed semester increases logarithm odd of inflated zero

<summary>
• Research on enzyme catalysis has shown that electrostatic interactions play a vital role in the process
• These interactions assist in ligand binding and facilitate chemical reactions by positioning and stabilizing reacting species
• Conformational changes during the catalytic cycle can significantly modulate these electrostatic interactions
• The study of these interactions and their impact on individual catalytic steps is a challenging but important goal
• The authors probed the changes in the active site electrostatic environment of Escherichia coli dihydrofolate reductase (ECDHFR) during its catalytic cycle using structural rearrangements
• The results provide valuable insights into the interplay between electrostatic and conformational changes along the catalytic cycle

• X-ray crystallographic, nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR), theoretical, and photophysical studies have shown that ECDHFR exhibits significant structural rearrangements along the catalytic cycle
• Thiocyanate probes were incorporated at site-specific locations to analyze the electrostatics and degree of hydration of the microenvironments surrounding the probes
• Vibrational and CNMR spectroscopic techniques, as well as computer simulations, were used to study the electrostatic interactions and conformational changes
• The electrostatic interactions arising from the active site microenvironments surrounding the probes led to different observed CN vibrational stretching frequencies and CNMR chemical shifts along the catalytic cycle
• Mixed quantum mechanical and molecular mechanical (QM/MM) analyses of classical molecular dynamics (MD) simulations were used to reproduce experimentally measured vibrational frequency shifts and examine the electric field along the hydride transfer pathway
• The study of the interplay between electrostatic and conformational changes along the catalytic cycle provides valuable insights into the mechanism of ECDHFR and enzyme catalysis in general
</summary>

		- Spio visualized directly by their change of magnetization in an oscillating magnetic field
		- Work like a tracer and not like a contrast agent
	+ *MRI signal generation:*
		- Spio work as an indirect contrast agent influencing the signal characteristics of the surrounding tissue
		- Occurs independently of the size of the spio, as long as they still have superparamagnetic characteristics

• Intracellular pathogens, like Leishmania, have evolved to coexist with host defense mechanisms

• In vitro studies of host-pathogen interaction exclude inflammatory milieu, while in vivo studies face challenges in distinguishing pathogen-specific responses from general inflammatory response

• General inflammatory response is driven by complement cascade, coagulation pathway, acute phase response, and inflammatory cytokines and chemokines, which affect phagocyte function

• Transcriptomic response of uninfected cells exposed to inflammation can serve as a measure of normal in vivo response to insult, with cell-intrinsic pathogen-induced changes observed in infected cells but not in uninfected cells

• In a Leishmania infection model, an RXRA-centered transcriptomic pathway is aberrantly maintained in infected Kupffer cells (KCs), leading to enhanced parasite survival and validating the use of cells exposed to inflammation to discover pathogen-regulated transcriptomic pathways

• KCs in the liver of uninfected mice have large size, express membrane GFP, and are in intimate contact with liver sinusoidal endothelial cells, exhibiting small fluctuations in cellular volume and surface area over time

• Injection of live Leishmania amastigotes in mice results in rapid increase in average shape factor and decrease in velocity in both infected and uninfected KCs, suggesting a cellular response to active infection

• Uninfected KCs in the immediate vicinity of infected cells also respond to the infection, indicating signals provided from infected KCs or activation of serum-derived mediators of inflammation

• Transcriptional events accompanying the observed change in KC behavior were examined by identifying and isolating KCs based on whether they contained parasites (infected) or not (inflamed) using flow cytometry analysis and fluorescence-activated high-speed cell sorting

</summary>

• Type of acrylic resin and surface treatment affect shear bond strength
• Control groups had significantly lower bond strength than treated groups
• Failure mode was predominantly mixed for Meliodent groups and adhesive for Futura Gen specimens
• Surface treatment with monomer effective in improving bond strength
• Airborne particle abrasion improved shear bond strength compared to untreated samples

• Higher diffusion rate of monomer at higher polymerization temperature
• Mechanical retention and increased surface area improve bond strength
</summary>

• The type of acrylic resin and surface treatment significantly affect the shear bond strength between denture teeth and denture base resins (Two-way analysis of variance (anova), f = 4.71, p = 0.03 and f = 21.09, p < 0.001, respectively).
• The control groups had significantly lower bond strength than the treated groups (p < 0.001), but there was no significant difference between the bond strengths of groups treated by monomer or airborne particle abrasion (p = 0.29).
• The failure mode was predominantly mixed in the Meliodent groups, whereas adhesive failure was reported for Futura Gen specimens.

• Surface treatment with monomer is an effective method for improving the bond strength between denture teeth and denture base resins.
• Airborne particle abrasion improved the shear bond strength compared to untreated samples.

• Higher diffusion rate of monomer at higher polymerization temperature results in better bond strength.
• Mechanical retention and increased surface area improve the bond strength between denture teeth and denture base resins.

<summary>

- **UVR Emitted During Arc Welding**
	+ Intense UV radiation (UVR) is emitted during arc welding, which can cause acute and delayed health effects in workers.
	+ UVR is emitted over the entire wavelength range excluding vacuum UVR, and its wavelength distribution varies depending on welding conditions.
	+ UVR from arc welding of steel consists mostly of a large number of spectral lines of iron scattered over this wavelength range.
- **Health Effects of UVR**
	+ Acute health effects of UVR include keratoconjunctivitis and erythema, while delayed health effects include cataracts and skin cancer.
	+ In a survey of 1667 workers at workplaces where arc welding is performed, 86% reported past experience with symptoms of uv keratoconjunctivitis, and 45% reported ongoing experience.
	+ Possible causes for this include workers mistakenly putting on their face shields after starting the arc or being exposed to UVR by co-workers performing arc welding nearby.
- **UVR Hazard and Protective Measures**
	+ The degree of hazard of the emitted UVR is thought to differ for each arc welding condition.
	+ It is necessary to examine the hazards of the UVR emitted during arc welding under various conditions to design protective measures.
	+ Local exhaust ventilation removes welding fume, which strongly mitigates UVR by scatter and absorption, and should be used to ensure that surrounding workers are not exposed to the UVR emitted by the arc.
</summary>

<summary>

• Bacterial cells with a higher content of PHA (polyhydroxyalkanoates) can survive longer due to their ability to utilize reserve material more efficiently.
• PHA are synthesized by many bacteria and archaea when carbon is available but other essential nutrients are not. They are divided into two groups based on the number of carbon atoms in their monomer units: SCL-PHA (short chain length) and MCL-PHA (medium chain length).
• The enzyme called PHA synthase plays a major role in PHA synthesis, and there are four classes of PHA synthases with different substrate specificities and subunit organizations.
• Extremophiles from polar areas are a source of novel enzymes with great economic potential in various industrial processes.
• The study aimed to determine whether bacteria from freshwater reservoirs in glacier forefield areas have the potential to synthesize PHA.
• Samples were collected from five shallow freshwater reservoirs and one stream located in the foreland of Ecology Glacier near the Polish Antarctic station Arctowski.

• GPS position, elevation, area, nutrient levels, pH, temperature, and conductivity were measured for each sampling site.
• Cells were scraped from the surface of slants and washed in sterile water, and DNA was extracted using a commercial kit.
• The partial 16S rRNA gene was amplified using specific primers, and PCR was performed with two primer pairs to detect microorganisms producing PHA.
• The first primer pair recognizes both SCL- and MCL-PHA synthase genes, while the second primer pair is specific for both genes responsible for MCL-PHA synthesis.
• The nucleotide sequences were submitted to the GenBank database, and the evolutionary distances were inferred using the neighbor-joining method.

</summary>

<summary>

- **Factors affecting successful establishment of vegetation:**

	+ **Rainfall:** Natural rainfall is crucial for the establishment of robust native or non-native vegetation, although its amount and distribution play a significant role.
	+ **Soil moisture:** Moisture levels in the soil are critical for seed germination and establishment, and irrigation can benefit exotic weeds more than natives.
	+ **Soil type:** The soil type used in simulations was a loamy sand, which is common in the region and the primary soil type on a nearby mineland reclamation site.
	+ **Seed depth:** The seeds were assumed to be in the top 0.1 cm of the soil when the monsoon rains began, corresponding well to visual observations of seed depth after broadcast seeding on this soil type in this area.
	+ **Seed fate:** All seeds were assumed to germinate when exposed to suitable monsoon conditions, and wetting events that did not result in germination were assumed to cause no injury to these warm-season perennial grass seeds.

- **Modeling and simulation of soil moisture:**

	+ **Model used:** The Noah land surface model was used in this study with multiple options for parameterization schemes of various land surface processes.
	+ **Data sources:** Seven years of eddy flux data were available, including temperature/relative humidity, photosynthetically active radiation, ground heat flux, soil temperature, precipitation, volumetric soil water content at different depths, wind velocity vector, sonic temperature, and concentrations of water vapor and carbon dioxide measurements.
	+ **Model calibration:** The model's hydraulic parameters were calibrated to match the observed soil moisture and surface energy and water fluxes from the flux tower data.
	+ **Model inputs:** The atmospheric forcing data to drive the model included hourly downward shortwave and longwave radiation fluxes, precipitation, air temperature, humidity, pressure, and wind speed.
	+ **Model outputs:** The model solved the one-dimensional Richards equation to account for redistribution of soil moisture among soil layers through diffusion and percolation processes.
</summary>

<summary>

- **Small RNA molecules and their importance in cell regulation:**
  - Small RNA molecules are crucial in regulating various molecular and biological activities in the cell.
  - Short RNA sequences play a critical role in regulating the expression levels of specific genes in a targeted manner.

- **RNA interference (RNAi) and gene regulation:**
  - RNAi is a gene regulatory mechanism that causes sequence-specific downregulation of mRNAs.
  - Double-stranded short interfering RNAs (siRNAs) can knock down expression levels via the RNA-induced silencing complex, which mediates degradation or translational inhibition of the targeted mRNAs.

- **RNAi and chromatin regulation:**
  - In fission yeast, homologs of the RNA-induced silencing complex can regulate chromatin through recruitment of histone-modifying proteins to loci transcribing small noncoding RNA.
  - This mechanism is also seen in plants, ciliates, nematodes, and flies.

- **Promoter-targeted RNAs and gene regulation:**
  - Small promoter-targeted RNAs have been shown to repress transcription and induce epigenetic changes in eukaryotic cells.
  - In human cells, short RNAs targeted to the promoter regions of certain genes can activate expression at the transcriptional level.

- **Designing sarnas for upregulation of specific cellular genes:**
  - A method has been developed to design sarnas for upregulation of specific cellular genes.
  - The feasibility and genetic consequences of upregulating important target genes involved in stem cell regulation and reprogramming have been studied.

- **Sarnas and stem cell reprogramming:**
  - Sarnas have shown significant potential as a tool for studying stem cell biology and as a safe method to manipulate stem cell gene expression without altering the genome.
  - Sarnas have been used to upregulate the expression of key reprogramming genes, such as Klf4 and c-Myc, in human mesenchymal stem cells.

</summary>

• UUO leads to renal disruption, tubular atrophy, degeneration, necrosis, and fibrosis

• Both taxol and taurine show protective effects on renal tissue damage in the UUO model

• Preserves volume of glomeruli, PCT, DCT, Henle's loop, and collecting ducts in UUO rats
• Decreases volume of degenerative tubules and necrotic and fibrotic tissues in UUO rats

	+ Increased focus on reducing allogeneic red blood cell (RBC) transfusions due to associated risks such as morbidity, mortality, infections, pathogen transmission, high costs, and blood shortage.
	+ PBM gaining attention in cardiac surgery, where postoperative bleeding is common and associated with increased morbidity and mortality, especially in elderly patients and those with long cardiopulmonary bypass.
	+ Factors contributing to excessive bleeding include surgical factors, impaired haemostasis, enhanced fibrinolysis, platelet dysfunction, haemodilution, acidosis, hypothermia, and consumption of coagulation factors.

- **Transfusion Guidelines and Practices:**
	+ Evidence-based guidelines recommend that RBC transfusions should not be based on a single haemoglobin (Hb) transfusion trigger, but rather on the patient's risk of developing complications of inadequate oxygenation.

	+ In major surgery, including cardiac and vascular surgery, the use of blood and blood products is still common, with 55.7% of European cardiac surgery patients receiving blood or blood products in the perioperative period.

* Neurogenesis in mammals occurs even after birth in specific tissues
* Olfactory epithelium has substantial anatomical and functional recovery in the face of injury
* Transplantation of a complex of cells, including olfactory ensheathing cells, fibroblasts, astrocytes, schwann cells, and olfactory epithelial multipotent stem and progenitor cells, is more effective for neural regeneration
* Olfactory epithelium contains at least two populations of cells with neuropotency: globose basal cells (GBCs) and horizontal basal cells (HBCs)
* GBCs are broadly multipotent progenitors capable of giving rise to neurons and all cell types of the epithelium
* GBCs differentiate into non-neuronal cell types during the regenerative process
* GBCs can be easily engrafted into the mebr-lesioned epithelium and give rise to most neural and non-neural cells
* Olfactory epithelial stem cells are the ideal candidate for clinical research and therapy due to their accessibility, biopsyability, and regeneration capability
* The basal compartment of the olfactory epithelium contains two morphologically distinct cell types, HBCs and GBCs, and researchers are studying the identification of the neural stem cell population
* This research work has isolated and deciphered numerous new facts about the GBCs in the olfactory epithelium of rats and has concluded that GBCs are the colony of neural stem cells responsible for ongoing neurogenesis in the oe throughout adult life.
	+ GBCs are neural progenitor cells, as confirmed by positive immunostaining with anti-NCAM, anti-nestin, and anti-Sox2
	+ GBCs are unexcitable and only have leaky potassium channels
	+ GBCs can be isolated in a pure form using FACS and gbc-iii antibody

- **Transposable elements (TEs)**:

<summary>

• Progressive diseases affecting millions worldwide (currently 45 million, expected to reach 76 million in 2030)
• Common characteristic: aggregation of misfolded or incorrectly eliminated polypeptides
• Ability to amplify and propagate from cell to cell, leading to self-sustaining vicious circle and disease
• Molecular chaperones play a central role in preventing protein misfolding, unfolding, and aggregation
• Cellular stress triggers heat shock response, leading to partial correction of misfolding/unfolding
• Ubiquitin proteasome system and autophagy responsible for clearing misfolded/unfolded proteins
• Misfolded protein aggregation can cause both loss of function and gain of pathologic function

• Hallmarks of neurodegenerative diseases: protein aggregates made of fibrillar material
• Number of deposits correlates with disease severity
• Misfolded protein aggregates propagation and amplification appears to be widespread in neurodegenerative diseases
• Indications for such a process originated from the work of Heiko Braak and colleagues
• Evidence for the transmission of misfolded protein aggregates not involving prion protein in man
• Injection of brain extracts containing protein aggregates induces lesions characteristic of diseases in model animals
• Fibrillar assemblies induced lesions months after injection in non-human primates, wild-type and model mice

• Aggregation of proteins associated with diseases can be reproduced in test tubes
• Pathologic htt-exon1 binds to cultured cells and induces the aggregation of sub-pathologic htt-exon1

* Separate meta-analyses were carried out in BRCA1 mutation carriers, BRCA2 mutation carriers, and among women who carried either BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutations

	+ Nearly all of the methods described are microfluidic, but some also incorporate nanoscale elements.
- Several novel size-based separation processes are being employed in micro- and nanoscale devices.
	+ These devices are compact, simple, and usually do not require additional energy sources or equipment.
- Maintaining cell viability is a major concern with size-based approaches, which do not require the presence of cell-specific markers or proteins to achieve separation.
	+ This approach can be used to isolate stem cells and other rare cells that do not express known markers.
- A technique for separating micron-sized particles with a resolution of 0.1 μm has been described by Huang et al.
	+ The technique allows for separation of fluids with a high resolution and with an uncertainty less than 1% of the particle size.

- Osteoporosis in patients with multiple sclerosis (MS) is caused by impaired bone strength and increased risk of fracture.
	+ Bone quality depends on macro- and microarchitecture and intrinsic properties such as matrix mineralization, microdamage accumulation, or collagen quality.
	+ Bone remodeling maintains bone structure and mechanical competence by removing damaged bone and replacing it with new bone.
- MS is a chronic progressive disease affecting young adults, particularly women, and impaired mobility or lack of weight-bearing physical activity can cause a marked imbalance in bone remodeling.
	+ Management of MS requires long-term disease-modifying therapy, such as glucocorticoids (GCS), which have a further negative effect on bone remodeling and bone strength.
	+ Secondary osteoporosis may develop, and low-trauma fractures occur more frequently in patients with MS than in healthy controls.
- Bone remodeling is underway throughout life and maintains bone strength by removing damaged bone and replacing it with new bone.
	+ Chronic diseases, such as MS, may significantly disturb the process of bone modeling and remodeling with resulting bone loss, deterioration of bone quality, and increased frequency of fractures.
	+ Secondary osteoporosis and low-trauma fractures occur in patients with MS more frequently than in healthy controls.
- The underlying pathogenic mechanisms of osteoporosis in patients with MS are probably based on progressive immobilization, long-term GCS treatment, vitamin D deficiency, skeletal muscle atrophy, and possibly on the presence of various cytokines involved in the pathogenesis of MS.
	+ Chronic use of other drugs, such as antidepressants, may contribute to the development of osteoporosis and fractures.

<summary>

* The life span of humans has increased, leading to a higher proportion of elderly people in the population
* In elderly men, lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS), erectile dysfunction (ED), and decreased libido often occur together
* Several studies have shown a strong correlation between sexual dysfunction, increasing age, and the severity of LUTS
* LUTS and ED share increased prevalence as age increases and often occur simultaneously
* The correlation between LUTS and ED may be due to overactivation of the autonomic nervous system and increased tension of the sympathetic nervous system
* A preliminary study found that age, International Prostate Symptom Score (IPSS), nocturia, and uroflow rate correlated significantly with the 5-item version of the International Index of Erectile Function (IIEF-5)
* Prostate gland volume was not significantly correlated with sexual function, implying that erectile function is not affected by subjective LUTS even with a relatively greater prostate size
